# Historical Notes

Historical Notes

**NETHERLANDS PIRATE**

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pier_Gerlofs_Donia

**IRON**

Indeed, the tendency of cities to accumulate unemployable laborers seems to have been a major motivator for many of the large-scale state building projects (like those of Pericles, or Augustus), effectively as ‘jobs programs’ at state expense; that such projects seem to have always found large and ready labor forces is telling. This inefficiency, an economy not well organized to effectively employ surplus labor, is a common feature of pre-modern economies, creating a ready supply of people desperate enough to do things like work in the mines merely to eat.

**ROME** 
Why Brutus failed the republic 
I was reading stuff about alchemy years ago, and they mention mine regeneration belief. Some of it was that the distinction between living matter and non-living matter didn’t exist in the way it does now. Mines were “alive”, sort of, because the Earth was. Like how you always hear about how alchemist either wanted to make gold or to make potions of immortality. To alchemists, these weren’t two different things, it was just about creating perfect versions of living stuff.

To the majority of Romans, the notion that their government represented them, allowed full accountability and participation was laughable. The government was in the hands of an indifferent elite, leeching off the glory, riches and power of the republic on the backs of thousands of plebs who worked for it. The majority of Romans must have been disillusioned with their government, and even before Caesar and Sulla became dictators, they must have felt like they were loosing their liberty anyways.
When Caesar, the charismatic, renowned, rich, politically astute aristocrat declares his support for the people against the *Optimates *they fall in love with him. When he becomes consul and passes the land reform bill, distributing public lands to citizens to farm via lottery this makes him popular as well.

**DESERT IRRIGATION**
Qanat - Persian design to keep water underground between aquifer so that it won't evaporate and salt the earth
Civilization emerges by irrigation 
ABU DHABI
Uses of wind capture, from traditional arab architecture design
Wind Funneling
Shade creation
Shikka Urban Wind tunnels

**MAYAN CALENDAR**
Maya had 18 20 day periods that made a year 
Base 20 number system 
Have underground rivers that are accessed by sinkholes 
Maya did not human sacrifice as much as Aztec 
Maya human sacrifice increased as they declined 

**DOGGERLAND SEA LEVEL RISE**
seeing the oceans rise miles inland over the course of a century due to it being a giant floodplain 
Culture develops that thinks the entire world will eventually be consumed by water 

**TOUCHSTONES**

Touchstone to compare stock metal and the metal in question by rubbing and comparing colors, using a ring on the touchstone
Also using acid to dissolve lesser materials in gold 

INTERNMENT 
For Japanese internment camps only 1/16 blood of Japanese dissent was needed also the camps were instituted by the military governor of the West Coast not by president executive order

**HERUCULANEIUM / POMPEII **

at pompeii, wood and bones decayed. at heruculaneum, they survived

**ROME - SIEGE LAW**

According to roman law, as soon as the first ram hit the city gates, the defenders lost any rights

**ALEXANDRIA - SCHOLARS**

Scholar society
Took all books that arrived on shore and gave owners copies back
Muses -> Museon -> Museum
Can address the scholars directly, duty as public intellectuals 
Tax exemptions and slaves
Asked for loan of book for deposit, instead kept the original and gave back a copy and let other keep deposit 
Libraries are starting become competitive in the region 
Kept originals because they liked to compare originals to compare for deviations and errors
“Critical Editions”

# Allen Ginsburg Flower Power

Allen Ginsburg fostered flower power and flower child movement, with social theater props like toys flat, candy and music, to make protests less intimidating 

In October 1967, Hoffman and Jerry Rubin helped organize the March on the Pentagon using Flower Power concepts to create a theatrical spectacle.[16] The plan included a call for marchers to attempt to "levitate" the Pentagon.

In his book, *Prometheus Rising*, the philosopher Robert Anton Wilson suggested that the flower children could be viewed in Jungian terms as a collective social symbol representing the mood of friendly weakness.[13] In 1995, *The Sekhmet Hypothesis* extended Wilson's idea into other pop cultural trends with other youth movements being compared to the moods of hostile weakness, friendly strength and hostile strength.[14]

Flower Child

items.full_text:
# Vietnam Heli Pilot Story Qoura



Vietnam Heli Pilot Story Qoura
**Don Funk**, former Marine Helo Pilot and Forward Air Controller
Answered March 23

H-34 Recon Mission Gone Awry
On a recon scouting mission west of Quang Ngai, our HMM-362 UH34D was targeted by an enemy 12.7mm nesting in a landscape of B-52 mud holes.
The 12.7 sounded like a .45 going off inches from my helmet. The crew chief yells, “They’re shooting at us, sir!” I was already doing evasive maneuvers, and got us out of there. We had to wonder where it was, and how they operated from those mud holes.
We had a single passenger, a senior Intel Marine scouting for upcoming insert and retraction zones for his Force Recon teams. He quickly let the crew chief know he wanted to take control of our flight path, telling the crew chief to tell me to “fly back over that area”.
I was pilot in command, and not about to do that. We were a single unaccompanied chopper with no backup way out in the boonies. We had just been almost shot out the sky by a large caliber weapon while at 3,000’ agl.
My hazy legal memory from flight training in Pensacola recalled that in situations such as this the airborne pilot maintains command, even over a senior officer, relating to safety-of-flight issues....unless the senior officer gives a direct order.
I instantly told the crew chief, “Put him on the mike!” (To this day, I don’t know where this wild thought came from except some mischievous Irish ancestor).
“You want me to give him my helmet?” “No, the one between my legs!”
“But sir, but but....that’s your piss tube!” “Yes, please give it to the Colonel.”
It had a neat spread lip that made it look like an old time megaphone on a hanging cord, and we pilots used it while flying, or more normally, on the ground, during hot refueling. It hung between our legs, and it sure could be mistaken for a communication device. It was also long enough to stretch rearward into the main H-34 cabin.
The Colonel spoke into the piss tube. He was apparently too intent on his mission to notice any smell! However, since I never got his orders, I didn’t have to obey them!
We did not re-fly over that 12.7 mud hole, though.
We dropped the Colonel off near the Chu Lai TAOR, then on to Ky Ha, where the crew laughed our tails off because he never knew what went down!
Captain Don Funk, USMCR RVN 1966-67
HAC HMM-362
FAC/ALO 7th Marines

items.full_text:
# Stacy on ALEXA 

https://staceyoniot.com/why-are-fewer-people-chatting-with-alexa/

## People mainly use Alexa for three things
More alarming is the data on reported use-cases. I bet you can guess them: Mainly to voice-control connected lights in the home, set timers, and play music. There’s little to no additional revenue in such services. But wait, you say: What about the massive number of Alexa Skills available that could generate income? Back in 2019, _there were a reported 80,000 such skills_, and this year _that number is estimated to be more than 100,000_.

*Image courtesy Amazon*

_Like I said in 2019_: There are a few reasons that this growth in skills hasn’t equated to similar engagement we’ve witnessed in the mobile app explosion. The reasons range from limitations of voice-only apps to all of us collectively trying to figure out what we need smart speakers to actually do for us; a question similar to “what do we want our smart homes to do?”

Discovering features on a smart speaker is hard, with little benefit

Smart displays have a better interface for many

https://staceyoniot.com/ive-seen-the-future-of-the-uwb-smart-home-and-i-want-it-now/

- Pointing your phone at a UWB device changes the phone menu option 

https://youtu.be/R8AFXMdouY8

items.full_text:
# Plants - Soil Design
**Soil**
*From Dust to Dust*
| = Or
|| = AndOr

General Soil
**Coco Coir || Peat Moss + Wood Ash || Local Soil || Compost**
-   Coco may contain trace bee killing pesticides (unverified)
-   Peat from bogs; relatively unsustainable
-   Coco shipped from tropical zones (transport emissions)
-   Local Soil has microbiome but also "pathogens"
-   Peat may have wrong PH unless limed, ashes can be used to raise pH
-   Local Soil or compost may have weed seeds

**Perlite || Asymmetrical Expanded Clay || Rice Hulls || Rocks || Biochar || Broken Clay Pots (Depends on Container, 25-33%)**
-   Aeration
-   Microbiotic Surface Area
-   Perlite relatively unsustainable, and transport emissions

**Worm castings (2-0-0) (20%)**
-   Beneficial Microbes, broken down bio available nutrients 

**Biochar (0-0-0) (8%)**
-   Easy harvest, medium processing 
-   _Remember to "activate" with worm tea compost_ (unverified)
-   Microbiotic surface area 

**Crustacean meal (4-4-0) (0.5%)**
-   Sea harvest, dry and grind processing 
-   Nitrogen and grows chitin eating microbio
-   May contain ocean contaminants (unverified)

**Seaweed Meal (2-0-3.5)(1%)**
-   Free sea harvest, dry and grind processing 
-   May contain ocean contaminants (unverified)
-   Aquatic plant disease has limited crossover (unverified)

**Bone Meal (3.5-17-0)(0.5%)**
-   Leftovers, bone broth
-   Throw in fire, or cook above fire
-   Processing: coffee bean grinder? solar kiln / solar dehydrator? [[Farm Todo#SolarKiln]]

**Blood Meal / Store Bought Organic Fertilizer** 
-   Expensive, less sustainable

-----------
**More Research Needed / Limited Scientific Citation**
_By Relevance_
( #unverified )
**Kelp meal: 1/4 cup per 5 gallons**
-   Trace minerals

**Neem Plant / Meal / Cake**
-   Pest resistance, ferts

**Humates** 
-   hummus of organically digested long term forest floor compost
-   contains potentially beneficial microbes 
-   Humid acid
-   Probably contained in leaf compost

**Worm Tea** / **Sugars**
-   Feed bacteria, probiotic supplement 

**Malted Seeds / Alfalfa / Blended**
-   Growth hormones

**EM (and or Nutritional Yeast?)**
-   Beneficial Microbe Nutrient Avail / probiotic supplement 
-   Inconclusive research

**Mychrozyzae / Inoculant** 
-   Root growth Fungi
-   Inconclusive research

items.full_text:
# Reflections on Psychics
      

**Psychics** 
#psychic #scifi 
I fundamentally don't understand the idea of "psychic energy"

  

Maybe its the result of mid century thinking, tinged with the mysticism of the early 20th century 

  

But in my current context it as an idea is so foreign to me 

  

It doesn't click 

  

How exactly did people think this psychic energy was created? Why would it not be detectable?

  

Why were they so willing to believe it?

  

Were there other undiscovered human senses? Why / what was the historical context in which the idea of an undiscovered human sense was even considered? Something to do with radio?

items.full_text:
# The Clean Garden
**"Clean" Garden Ideas**

_To Reduce possible exposure to man-made carcinogens_

  

-   Don't use store bought potting soil (made from composted forest products and municipal compost -> municipal sources are usually tainted 
-   Don't use pulp products such as cardboard, paper towels, napkins (Kymene, micro plastics from recycled pulp, and maybe inks?)
-   Don't use dryer lint unless you go completely nylon / polyester free (Microplastics)
-   using wood chips, make sure it comes from somewhere without pesticide / herbicide use (Herbicides, Pesticides, Garbage/Microplastics)
-   Don't use pallets (may have preservation chemicals?)
-   Don't use landscape fabric or fiberglass tarps (or anything with synthetic fibers that will degrade with sun exposure)
-   Don't use pvc or lead based garden hoses 

  

These are guidelines depending on your level of cautiousness. I use landscape fabric in small amounts, I use wood chips, I use dry lint from cotton towels (despite potential nylon fiber contamination), I use pulp products like paper towels, I use shredded paper which has ink on it, I have used store bought potting soil.

 Upon the garden of Epicurus (published in 1690), which contrasted European theories of symmetrical gardens with asymmetrical compositions from China, for which he introduced the Japanese term [_sharawadgi_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharawadgi).[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_landscape_garden#cite_note-19)[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_landscape_garden#cite_note-chang-2010-28-20)[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_landscape_garden#cite_note-stepanova-21) 

  

Chinese gardens, asymmetry -> English Gardens

Stephen Switzer, in _The Nobleman, Gentleman and Gardener's Recreation_ (1715), describes the practice of the _ferme ornée_ "By mixing the useful and profitable parts of Gard'ning with the Pleasurable in the Interior Parts of my Designs and Paddocks, obscure enclosures, etc. in the outward, My Designs are thereby vastly enlarg'd and both Profit and Pleasure may be agreeably mix'd together". His English readers would detect, in the juxtaposition of useful and pleasurable, the classical view of the twin aims of poetry, inherited from [Horace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horace), "to instruct and to delight".

  

  

**Lancelot Brown** (born c. 1715–16, baptised 30 August 1716 – 6 February 1783),[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability_Brown#cite_note-Lancelot-1) more commonly known as **Capability Brown**, was an English [landscape architect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_architect). He is remembered as "the last of the great English 18th-century artists to be accorded his due" and "England's greatest gardener".

He designed over 170 parks, many of which survive. He was nicknamed "Capability" because he would tell his clients that their property had "capability" for improvement.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability_Brown#cite_note-2)

  

  

[Richard Owen Cambridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Owen_Cambridge), the English poet and [satirical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satire) author, declared that he hoped to die before Brown so that he could "see heaven before it was 'improved'."

  

Are we approaching (or currently in) and age of Cottage Orné? Rustic rebellion to the technological rapid development of the last 15 years?

items.full_text:
# Economics of Space Colonization
**Space Mining**
#space #space-mining #future #scifi #economics

I think resource extraction by itself is a fairly fallacious motivation for space travel. As soon as someone can undercut you on earth, and given the costs of traversing material back and forth to the moon, your entire pipeline is running below market value. The best method may be to allow billionaires to own whatever they colonize and make property staking the motivation for space travel

items.full_text:
# The Forever War
**THE FOREVER WAR** 
#reflection-on-media #reflection #scifi #book #novel
Review 
I was very susceptible to the romantic events in the forever war, but the action and interactions with other squad mates could have been handled better. Of course, falling in at about only 300 pages, The Forever War is a short novel. The sense of melancholia and trudger throughout the galaxy adds to this slow build but feels like it never amounts to anything great (which I suppose is the purpose of the novel, that wars leads to nothing). The Taurans design was also not to my liking. They weren't as interesting as they could have been, but there are reasons for everything I disagree about. I would argue that The Forever War isn't really a military science fiction novel that focusses on the military, but rather the war and the somewhat poor hard science fiction. The military is primitive, use no air support or APC’s, rather building bases and sitting inside them. The ending with the “spears” and quarterstaffs” was also confusing to its purpose.

items.full_text:
# Dunkirk
**DUNKIRK THOUGHTS**
2018
#reflection-on-media #reflection #ww2 #movie #film
@Bryce Dillard the point was atonement portrayed the soldiers as humans who amongst absurdity, attempted to mask the horror through ignorance, and denial. This is best seen when the big black dude is the only one who cares about the shot horses. Dunkirk only imbued certain individuals with agency that attempted to best circumstance and systematic disenfranchisement through malice and some ultimate heroism. The inclusion of good soldiers was to balance the portrayal of British infantry without bias towards bad or good and isolate the bad as independent cases. While both solid portrayals, the oner shot vindicates humans as victims of circumstance in an absurd world, humanizing the entirety of the soldiers rather than victims of dramatized human malice. Where Dunkirk views individual agency, and the secret and sneaky cruelty of humanity as the solution to a dumber greater world of systematic disenfranchisement, Atonement addresses the trauma of mass disenfranchisement through the more realistic portrayal of human acceptance and lack of agency.

# WW2 Fighter Canons VS Machine Guns
**Ww2 Fighter Canons VS Machine Guns** 
#airplane #plane #fighter #ww2 #history #warfare #war
-   Plane armor is mainly designed to defend pilot and gas tanks 
-   Because maneuverability was less important on a bomber, they could hav more armor
-   Germany used more canons because they had to face a heavy bomber threat from the US, therefore to defeat armor and or larger fuselage, AP, incendiary, and timed explosive fused guns were used, which allowed effectiveness against both fighters and bombers
-   Us used 50 cals because it was sufficient for fighter-on-fighter and strafe runs against non tank vehicles, shared tooling with other 50 cals. But as a result that had to have 2-3 times the amount of guns on the plane(around 6) to be effective
-   Weapon system (2-3 cannons vs 4-6 machine guns) per pound was probably similar

# Chinese Space Deterrence 

[https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RRA943-1.html](https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RRA943-1.html)

RAND

“China's view of space as a critical U.S. vulnerability makes U.S. space capabilities attractive targets for attack. Highlighting China's own reliance on space-based capabilities should be a part of a tailored deterrence strategy.”

// My prediction is the viability of satellite warfare will increase and therefore human habitation of low earth orbit will decrease in the coming decades

“the United States needs to continue to develop and demonstrate an ability to attribute attacks on its space systems in order to establish credible and assured retaliation.13 The importance of devel- oping these capabilities is reflected in the increasing prioritization of space domain awareness (SDA) in the USSF and United States Space Command.14”

“China may seek to establish a legitimacy for its own actions in space by messaging that the United States has already violated the peaceful use of space. One primary source document asserts that the establishment of USSF is one such example of a violation of the international system of the peaceful use of space.18”

“China could also engage in a messaging campaign that attempts to divide the United States from its allies by asserting that USSF is engaging in destabilizing activities that it has not disclosed to these allies.”

“Second, the United States might seek ways of demonstrating that it is not as highly dependent on satellite-enabled warfare as Beijing has come to believe in recent years. As discussed above, China assesses that U.S. satellites were an essential enabler of Washington’s successful joint military operations against Iraq. In order to modify Chinese percep- tions that the United States is heavily reliant on space and therefore reduce Beijing’s focus on space deterrence, Washington could publicly reveal new capabilities outside of the space domain, such as advanced surveillance remote piloted vehicles or new communications systems, which demonstrate redundancy of its space-based capabilities. Devel- oping and messaging the existence of this redundancy could encour- age China to reconsider the value of taking escalatory steps in space. From this perspective, the establishment of USSF is counterproduc- tive because the new service implies that Beijing is correct—that is, that the United States does highly value outer space and must defend it at all costs to avoid vulnerabilities on Earth.”

// Contrary to what I said previously, in the short term it actually behooves us as the dominant power in space to put more humans

items.preview:
# Techno Authoritarian Skepticism 
[**Yuval Noah Harari**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOmQqBX6Dn4)
created:: 2022-02-25

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOmQqBX6Dn4](https://www.youtube.com/watc
items.full_text:
# Techno Authoritarian Skepticism 
[**Yuval Noah Harari**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOmQqBX6Dn4)
created:: 2022-02-25

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOmQqBX6Dn4](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOmQqBX6Dn4)

Rallying against techno-authoritarianism is an older form, and at least for me whats being said here is an older form of similar ideas. What zuboff instead emphasizes to a greater degree is stepping back and recontextualizing techno-utopian narratives, as derived from what was stated directly by those in power (CEO's, politicians), taken to logical extremes  
he does bring up a similar point to zuboff in that there are asymmetries of awareness over the true magnitude of big data  
while similar in that (techo-dystopian prevention vs techno-utopian skepticism) are sort of inverses of each other, the latter is a different perspective, because it involves less other-izing. It is not a looming threat, but is already fundamentally integrated into our daily lives, just in the past decades phrased publicly in mostly positive terms.  
  
Currently we are of course of the downslope of cyclical techno-optimism, moving into 70's-esque techno-pessimism  

I really like his way of using the data lens of analysis  
  
that democracy / market based information processing was more efficient that authoritarian regimes given the technology  
  
I the data lens of analysis, there is however in this a blind spot I think. To fear techno-authoritarianism presupposes that the technology is sufficient to actually bring about a techno-authoritarian state. I do not think this is obvious, nor a given.  
  
I am skeptical because it feels similar to 20th century regimes that also claimed they could rule directly efficiently due to their at the time advanced technology (mechanization, mass communication), and people in the west also feared it.  
  
Now, it may be that current technology IS sufficient to bring about techno-authoritarianism. However the very nature of the narrative being oft-repeated is in itself, to me, a cause for hearty doses of skepticism. Especially when these techno-dystopian fears are couched in the later half of the techno-optimistic era

items.full_text:
# US Ag, Value Added, Food Dollar, Identity Preservation
#political-economy #agriculture #business #logistics
created:: 2022-02-22

Is our last competitive value added commodity physical export, which is why we have such a vested interest in making people obese and "foodies" 

[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture)

-   Changing methods of production (organic, free-range) to differentiate product and capture more of consumer dollar than just selling commodity produce 

In this strategy, farming is no longer confined to the cultivation of vast tract of land or the care for a large number of animals in order to be profitable. Here, even those who own less than an acre could achieve viable farming simply by extending an agricultural product's potential so that its saleability is enhanced.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-:0-3) For example, if a producer farms strawberries, he should not only sell the crop as fresh berries since he could also profit from its other portions by producing other products such as strawberry jelly and syrup.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-:0-3)

According to the study, value-added agriculture allows farmers to capture as much as 80 percent of the value of most of their agricultural produce.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-5)

This concept has gained currency in the [small farm policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Small_farm_policy&action=edit&redlink=1) debate, in response to the concern that the farm value of the consumer food dollar continues to decrease. Value-added agriculture might be a means for farmers to capture a larger share of the consumer food dollar. Examples include [direct marketing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_marketing); farmer ownership of processing facilities; and producing farm products with a higher intrinsic value (such as [identity-preserved](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity-preserved) grains, [organic produce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organic_product), [organic beef](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organic_beef), [free-range chickens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free-range_chicken); etc.), for which buyers are willing to pay a higher price than for more traditional bulk commodities. The key for the higher returns is the high-demand in [product niches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_market) and this is demonstrated in the popularity of products such as garlic braids, bagged salad mix, artisan bread, lavender soaps, and sausages, among others.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-:2-1)

Value-added agriculture is regarded by some as a significant rural development strategy. In the United States, this is considered a way for producers not only to increase their income but also compete with commodity marketers and upstream processors.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-:1-4) Small-scale, organic food processing, non-traditional crop production, [agri-tourism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agri-tourism), and [bio-fuels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bio-fuels) development are examples of various value-added projects that have also created new jobs in some rural places. This favorable condition is encouraged by the increasing [market segmentation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_segmentation) which creates an uptick in the demand for high-quality and differentiated agricultural products.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-:1-4) According to a study, value-added agriculture allows farmers to capture as much as 80 percent of the value of most of their agricultural produce.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value-added_agriculture#cite_note-5)

Value-added processing offers farmers the potential to capture a larger share of the food dollar. The farmer's share of the

# US Public Health Thoughts
#healthcare 
created:: 2022-03-03

Theres money to be made on suckers, and money to be saved on the early dead.

The state's incentive is to have less unproductive old people that productive young people to support the, because it is better for the economy. I think we have effectively decreased the pre 55 mortality rate to a sufficient degree now that any incentives to increase public health will be marginal at best. 

(This is an instance where identifying conflicting incentives can inform how you view systems that supposedly act in your interest.)

# Everything as a Metaphor
#language #linguistics
2022-03-11
Increasing comprehension and critical thinking

Categories are a metaphor (technically "metonym") in which a thing is represented using another thing (when in a similar domain, metonym), whereas a metaphor is mostly cross domain. In the literary sense, phrases can be interpreted as either or both, ex. "Lend me your ear". 

Wikipedia : **Metonymy** ([/mɛˈtɒnəmi/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English))[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metonymy#cite_note-1) is a [figure of speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figure_of_speech) in which a thing or concept is referred to by the name of something closely associated with that thing or concept.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metonymy#cite_note-2) Ex. The pentagon

Barnett uses the more common term "optics" and "filter" as his metaphor for understanding the application of "frameworks" of thought 

I use metaphor in the "Its just a metaphor, its not literal" in the Jordan Peterson Bible lecture sense 

For example, there is no Platonic world of forms Kantian "thing in itself" for "The Iron Age." The "Iron Age" is merely a metaphor / filter / framework / category that describes a time period with a shared set of features. Like a metaphor, the connection is tenuous, with time and changing understanding and definitions, it is subject to revision ("dead metaphor"). 

[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_metaphor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_metaphor)

Religion is metaphor in that it uses narrative and ritual to provide meaning without literal 'spelling it out.'

// pretty inefficient, although as meaning seems to be truly internally derived, the loose associations in religion allow people over long timespans to utilize the same ideas in differing ways

The recent interest in gender is the clearest example of popular questioning of categories, but I would wager most people don't ever question a category of things or consider skeptically that a category is a metaphor representing the gradated mass via abstraction.

Metaphor in my estimation is the use of abstraction to compress and or translate meaning into more communicable or more digestible forms. 

**Categorization** is the human ability and activity of recognizing shared features or similarities between the elements of the [experience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience) of the world (such as [objects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_(philosophy)), events, or [ideas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idea)), organizing and classifying experience by associating them to a more abstract group (that is, a category, class, or type),[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorization#cite_note-Croft2004ch4-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorization#cite_note-2) on the basis of their traits, features, similarities or other criteria.

Religion - How to act (ritual, morals) given the presence of external powers (viewed critically, the metaphorical explanations of things that aren't currently well understood).

"Everything is Metonymy" isn't exactly as catchy 

is a [figure of speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figure_of_speech) in which a thing or concept is referred to by the name of something closely associated with that thing or concept.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metonymy#cite_note-2)

Sometimes, metaphor and metonymy may both be at work in the same figure of speech, or one could interpret a phrase metaphorically or metonymically. For example, the phrase "[lend me your ear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friends,_Romans,_countrymen,_lend_me_your_ears)" could be analyzed in a number of ways. One could imagine the following interpretations:

-   Analyze "ear" metonymically first – "ear" means "attention" (because people use ears to pay attention to each other's speech). Now, when we hear the phrase "Talk to him; you have his ear", it symbolizes he will listen to you or that he will pay attention to you. Another phrase "lending an ear (a

# Cantonese Architecture
#history #architecture #china
```toc
```
## Lingnan Region
-   **Cold alleys or 冷巷**, are designed such that air speed increases in the narrow passage, thus cooling warmer rooms 
-   **Narrow Doors or  隘門**, are defensive entrances that narrow at strategic points.
-   DO NOT ENTER THE ANCESTOR HALL AT NIGHT!!!!
[https://www.hisour.com/lingnan-architecture-29289/](https://www.hisour.com/lingnan-architecture-29289/)

## Overall
Overall, the classical Lingnan style, which is the best-known of Lingnan architecture, tends to favor pale colors such as green and white, avoid circular structures, adopt large numbers of relief carvings and sculptures, have many open structures like balconies and verandas, and be built using materials resistant to molds and moisture. The last two points are obviously related to the hot and humid subtropical climate of Lingnan

items.full_text:
# Brasilia
#architecture #brazil #urban-planning

Total state control of development was critical to the creation of utopian high modernist cities by the CIAM, as it prevented conflict between the planned ideal society and the incoherence of imposing this model on existing conditions.[24]

Following the completion of the city, it became apparent that Brasília’s high modernist design had overlooked the complexities of urban space and had overestimated the ability of functional, rational design to improve socio-political order. Planners’ focus on orienting mobility in the city around automobile traffic had eliminated the street as a place for public gathering; the removal of street corners in favour of cul-de-sacs and open space (punctuated by monumental sculptural and architectural forms like the Cathedral of Brasília and the National Congress Building) discouraged pedestrian traffic, traditional social networking and organic growth of public space.[25] The organization of Brasília's settlement similarly restricted social space by collectivizing residents according to their occupation in the ‘’superquadra’’, transforming the private sphere of the home into a space where the individual was ‘symbolically minimized.’ [26] While these ‘’superquadra’’ featured their own educational, entertainment, recreational and retail facilities to meet any perceivable need of the city’s residents, these perceived needs were based on European models from CIAM and architect Le Corbusier. Furthermore, the aesthetic monotony and scale of the city’s built environment created feelings of isolation, forced conformity and disorientation among residents; there also existed a stark contrast between the wealthier residents living in the centre of the city and the poorer residents situated along the city’s margins.[27]

items.full_text:
# Popper, Kuhn, Lakatos
Philosophy of Science

#philosophy #science #logic

[Post-Kuhnian Philosophy of Science: Imre Lakatos (2 of 3) - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ezJH8MTgTxQ)

## Hume / Popper
Hume Problem of Induction -> we assume that future events will play out like past events

// belief is a statistical / provisional construct 

Popper on Hume -> be willing to revise ideas and admit wrong 

Hypotheses do not always come from empiricism (observation)and can be divorced form evidence (I doubt this on a neurological level)

You can never PROVE a theory -> the more confident we are, the higher verisimilitude, if a theory resists falsification 

If we rely on this deductive logic, there never is the problem of deduction 

However, just because something is falsifiable does not mean it is science ("hey, astrology is wrong, but since its falsifiable its science!")

## Kuhn

"Anomalies are not counter examples" - Kuhn

// compounding and persistent anomalies are what matters

Kuhn would agree with Taleb in that Popper should not lecture birds on how to fly

Kuhn -> science works because of the balance between close mindedness on axiomatic fundamentals and open minded to self skepticism and anti-dogmatism 

Popper wants to remove inductive logic from "science" however that does not work with how science practically works 

Falsifiability 

Kuhn -> predictive power is useful and therefore that is what chooses the dominant paradigm 

Kuhn -> no matter how much data you have there will always be competing paradigms that use that same data for their paradigm 

Kuhn -> we are not progressing towards truth 

// we are progressing towards predictive ability / problem solving 

However, if psychics are a valid problem solving method they are not inferior to science, but generally they are not as useful at problem solving 

Kuhn's "5 Ways"

-   Accuracy of prediction 
-   Consistency within itself and other theories 
-   Scope (?)
-   Simplicity (should create order)
-   Fruitful (should allow for further research)

Incommensurability -> no common measure 

## Imre lakatos 
-   Predictability is a healthy theory "research program"
-   "Degenerative" vs "progressive"
-   Just because a program is currently degenerative doesn't mean we should abandon it (ex. Neural nets)
-   Marxism was "degenerative" because its predictions were wrong (communism appeared in Russia in a agrarian rather than industrial society)
-   You can not determine without historical perspective if a program is degenerative or progressive 
-   Believes the philosophers of science job is to make the history of science seem rational (retrospective rationality)
-   "History should be heuristic not empirical" -> "history is a test of philosophy not a means of discovering historical fact"

items.full_text:
# Limits of Language in Technology
#robots #linguistics #language #philosophy #metaphor
2021-08-05

I think the term "robot" has actually become detrimental to our ability to develop novel ideas in automation

theres this deep assumption, useful but eventually detrimental, with for example online social worlds / vr (the belief they will be like ready player one IE a relatively one to one mapping of the physical meatspace into a digital representation), previous century ideas on space travel being just like age of sail travel, that traditional human / nature metaphors are the way that technology will be most effectively applied

the best example is how renaissance thinkers were trying to create ornithopters that mimicked birds, because it was the most obvious meatspace-existing metaphor we could apply

and eventually people developed the realities of the thing and now a 747 could hardly be compared to a bird, at least mechanically speaking

in a similar way, the word "robot" presupposes alot of meatspace mapping - the traditional humanoid golem robot or boston dynamics "dog" are a a perfect example of this
vs what "robots" are today, a relatively artificial delineation / dichotomy between a amazon warehouse arm, a 3D printer, and 90s japanese ASIMO "they use it in disaster zones" humanoid bullshit

in the same way that early iphone used skeuomorphic (the game room app looked like a physical game room) design because they had to adjust users to the novel interface, or how our idea of the popular desktop os (which started adoption in offices) is based on the metaphor file cabinets

I have a bone to pick with the use of the metaphor of folders and I know [**@Ricardo Solis**](https://www.facebook.com/100001870842755) youve expressed a similar dissatisfaction with it

2021-08-05

//Code is like math that's harder to debug objectively speaking but easier from a human language based reasoning standpoint   

[https://friesian.com/calculus.htm](https://friesian.com/calculus.htm)

infinitesimals in calculus do not "exist" in the real world in the sense that they have no physical body but I feel like they are fundamental to existence in that higher order representations of a thing are valid representations of the things they are composed of (how do I express this without being pedantic??)

Philosophically (and by that I mean as a tool in the toolkit of viewing reality), I think the idea of calculus and the limit, that the distance between two points can be so infesemally small that we just consider them a single object (the limit)

Theres also something poetic about "never reaching the limit but acting as if it is X"

In a philosophical sense its like learning that as an object approaches being another object else it effectively, for all intents and purposes, becomes the something 

I feel like I do not have the words to describe this concept, likely due to my limited understanding of math, set theory, class theory, etc.

_"The principle would be that similar to what we find with_ [_imaginary numbers_](https://friesian.com/imagine.htm)_, i.e. we have an entity that exists in representation, that does not correspond to a real object, perhaps because of some contradiction, but which does enable us to derive results for real objects...._

_The concept of "nothing" is thus certainly useful in our representation, and gives real results, despite its birth in paradox._

#article #clip

# The Great Demise of the File
#article #clip
_30 Jul 2009 »_ [_permalink_](http://www.mdk.org.pl/2009/7/30/the-great-demise-of-the-file)

I recently had an HDD failure and had to dig deep into the filesystem to recover some data. Pain in the ass. While navigating the crummy, hidden folders to recover weirdly-sounding filenames… an epiphany hit me — _The File_ is dying. The metaphorical role of a file is dying. The file used to be the beginning and the end — it contained an essay, a book, a photo, a song, a todo list, a business card… to give you a document I would put the file containing it on a disk. Or on a usb stick. Or I would send it via email.

The piece of information **was** the file and vice versa: the file **was** the piece of information.

But not so much anymore. The email program does not operate on files. Neither does the twitter client nor the todo-tracking application. They store data in well-hidden databases in the internal directories that we’re not supposed to look at. And quite rightly — because there is nothing to see there. Looking at the huge _photos.db_ one might only wonder where his dog photos are.

Sure, the applications still give you a way to share things and take them out of the storage. You can export a contact out of your address book as a vcard file. But the role of _The File_ here is slowly being reduced to a role of an intermediate storage medium. The business card is temporarily put in the _.vcf_ file before it gets injected into somebody else’s database (another address book?).

As more and more applications operate on databases, the computer is becoming a monolithic _black-box_ that “has things”. How exactly (and where) the data is stored is becoming less clear. The application and the interface becomes united with the user data. It becomes one.

And if I own your user interface, I own your data.

**Not so good**

Databases as storage mediums solve problems by creating new ones.

I've got a directory on my disk that contains stuff related to my [company](http://www.new-wild.com/) – documents, invoices and some other content which is still mostly file-based. But I also have a todo list related to my work things and some notes about current projects. These are stored in two separate applications that operate on their own storage. So now: if I copy the whole company directory to another medium I'm not effectively copying everything. This trivial issue is extremely confusing for most users who are not familiar with the application internals.

There are other technical issues as well. Apple’s [Time Machine](http://www.apple.com/macosx/what-is-macosx/time-machine.html) is a good example here. It’s a great backup service but it was designed to operate on files. When a file is modified locally Time Machine copies it to a backup storage. This way it’s fast and incremental – the changes are small and isolated. You can even browse various versions of the file from the past. But if your “file” is a monolithic 1GB notes & pictures database (it’s “everything”) the whole concept is blown away (ie. [Yojimbo](http://www.mail-archive.com/yojimbo-talk@barebones.com/msg01151.html) example).

**Meet the service**

Not surprisingly, we stopped talking “files” long time ago. We’re talking “services” now. In some cases it works great: in example, I don’t exactly care how my Linux, Mac or iPhone email client store the mail data. I don’t care because the central storage (my IMAP server) is out there and it has a clear, well-defined service API. It’s transparent.

Too bad that email is a lonely exception here. Quite a significant portion of the data generated by us today is put in totally black-boxed, closed services that are very open to _take_ our data but not very keen on _giving it back_ in a sane way. This is often a deliberate business practice but sometimes – a lack of thought. Social services like [Facebook](http://www.facebook.co

# Chomsky on Blogging
#chomsky #social-media #internet #clip
2022-07-06

[Let’s all go back to Tumblr | Hacker News](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17796129)

[teddyh](https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=teddyh) [on Aug 21, 2018](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17807952) [[–]](javascript:void(0))
> But a great many serious things cannot be articulated in 140 or 280 characters, and so_ [on Twitter] _you get the most easily reducible — and therefore least accurate — version of the feeling or idea. Either that, or you get lengthy Twitter threads, which are ponderous and boring._ 

This is quite similar to Noam Chomsky’s idea of the media requiring “concision”¹, and therefore the media can only express mainstream ideas, since non-mainstream ideas require a little bit of explanation and so cannot be expressed concisely.

1. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concision_(media_studies)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concision_(media_studies))

[philwelch](https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=philwelch) [on Aug 21, 2018](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17804395) [[–]](javascript:void(0))

The medium is the message. Twitter is designed like a platform for harassment, so a lot of the content on Twitter is harassing. Tumblr is designed like a platform for radicalization, so a lot of the content on Tumblr is radicalized.

It turns out that your very advice ("don't make your social circle out of the people who create weird and distasteful fringe content") is the exact same echo-chamber-and-radicalization-mechanism that filled Tumblr with this kind of crap in the first place.

items.full_text:
# Chinese Room, Semantics Ramble
Ramblings on Semantics
#philosophy 
2019-05-22

The Chinese room has a man that can syntactically respond to Chinese. Searle claims “Syntax is not sufficient for semantics,” however I argue that this is a relative function of syntax as semantics is also a relative variable. As one comprehends more syntax, possibly from other domains, they increase in semantic understanding. However, “true understanding” as an infinite, unreachable end state of semantics, can only be approached towards infinity, it can never be reached. However, this means pragmatically that we can in fact create a machine that understands semantics at the level in which we assume a human does (we assume the human is the end state), just by increasing levels of syntactical understanding. Just as we in the 3rd dimension can visually contextualize a 4rth dimensional cube by reduction to 3 dimensions, we never can truly “understand” in the 4rth dimensional perception of the 4d cube, however we can approach understanding. Effectively, this means that through syntax we can comprehend and therefore act upon (mathematically in this case) n dimensional objects. However, assuming that we can never perceive them, we will never reach semantic “true understanding”, despite pragmatically approaching all functions on them by reduction and expansion, or projection. 

Cognitive scientist Margaret Boden argues in [1] that the human brain is not the carrier of intelligence, but rather that it _causes_intelligence. Analogously, the person in the room _causes_ an understanding of Chinese to arise, even though it does not understand Chinese itself.

Culmulative Syntax = The sum of ((level of syntax n)+(level of syntax (n+1))+…..)/n where n equals the domains of syntactical knowledge

As Culmulative Syntax approaches infinite syntax, it also approaches infinite semantics (true understanding).

Semantics are a function of cumulative, relative syntax 

Semantics in a domain D = D*semanticleveofD+AnotherDomainD2*semanticleveofD2+…

Selection of domains <- indeterminate, needs to be something that the more relevant the domains the larger semantics of domain d emerges

items.full_text:
# A Heuristic for Note Organization
#note-taking 
Thoughts on philosophy of note taking and note usage 
- Organization should be mostly emergent.
	- Searching and indexing (automated) should be the primary method of organization, empowered by metadata like back linking, concept::definition, date. 
	- Like websites, notes should be organized horizontally (group of tabs / pages) or linearly (text), or even better like mobile websites, linearly with headings. 
- Personally, for cross domain thinking, attempt to minimize hierarchy. Things overlap to a great degree and rigid hierarchy / categorization silos not very useful for synthesis. Vertical hierarchy is good for recall / memory but not great for idea synthesis, which requires lateral exploration. 
	- Folders are useful for manual search and manual organization, and therefore probably high levels of recall, but not recognition.
- Hierarchy is good for exploration // in what instances?
- Naming tags
	- Tag should not be in the text. 
		- The more uncommon the word, the more likely the search result will be accurate.
		- The tag should be a meta category
	- Tag inflation is inevitable, so tags must be aliased. 
	- Tags do not work in small datasets. Only work given sufficient coverage and ranking from multiple taggers.

items.full_text:
# Aurelius 'Meditations' Notes
2020-07-15

## Aurelius
Think about your life: childhood, boyhood, youth, old age. Every transformation, a kind of dying. Was that so terrible? Think about life with your grandfather, your mother, your adopted father. Realize how many other deaths, and transformations, and endings there have been, and ask yourself: was that so terrible? Then neither will the close of your life be - its ending and transformation. (Marcus Aurelius, Meditations)

At dawn when you have trouble getting out of bed, tell yourself, "I have to go to work, as a human being. What do I have to complain of, if I'm going to do what I was born for - the things I was brought into the world to do? Or is this what I was created for - to huddle under the sheets and stay warm?" (Marcus Aurelius, Meditations)

"It's unfortunate that this happened." No. It's fortunate that this has happened and I've remained unharmed by it - not shattered by the present or frightened of the future. It could have happened to anyone. But not everyone could've remained unharmed by it. (Marcus Aurelius, Meditations)

Choose not to be harmed, and you won't feel harmed. Don't feel harmed, and you haven't been. (Marcus Aurelius, Meditations)

Soon you'll be ashes, or bones. A mere name at most, and even that is just a sound, an echo. (Motivation to live.)

Then what should we work for? Only this: proper understanding, unselfish action, truthful speech. A resolve to accept whatever happens as necessary and familiar, flowing like water from that same source and spring. (Good life goals.)

“The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.”

_Questionable for a given definition of “insane”_

“How much more grievous are the consequences of anger than the causes of it.”

## Seneca
Associate with people who are likely to improve you. Welcome those whom you are capable of improving. The process is a mutual one: men learn as they teach.

Self-contented as he is, then, he does need friends - and wants as many of them as possible - but not to enable him to lead a happy life. This he will have even without friends. The supreme ideal does not call for any external aids, it is homegrown and entirely self-developed. Once it starts looking outside itself for any part of itself, it is on the way to being dominated by Fortune. (Seneca, Letters from a Stoic)

 "Not growing up with a father figure" issue. I have decided that Marcus Aurealis is my actual father, and Socrates is my great uncle and Thales is my grand father.

items.full_text:
# Theology Notes
#philosophy 

How does one define god 

Theology is a philosophical assessment of god 

What characteristics in god?

God is singular 

Could God create a stone so heavy, that he can’t lift it?

Could God be evil 

Does god define good or does god know all good and therefore it exists external of god?

Acquinas 

Aristotelian 

Cosmological Proof

Everything has cause 

No thing can cause itself it exist 

Deductive argument 

If everything has a cause, then god must not have a cause, and therefore contradicts it 

Paley 

Teleological Proof

-things seem to be designed because the purpose is too deliberate 

After having read the articles for the week and having listened to lecture, what do you think?  Are either of the arguments compelling?  If not, what is flawed in the arguments.  You may discuss the potential flaws that I identify, or you may indicate those that occur to you.  If you do find them compelling, what is it that you find convincing.  Do you think your own tendencies toward belief or disbelief affect your ability to view these arguments impartially?

The Cosmological Proof seems to follow and make sense. Everything has cause, and no thing can cause itself to exist. God is the only thing exempt from this. Scientifically, however, the beginning fo the universe suggests that things we can no longer interact with can be the cause or previously inter actable with things. However, I do not agree with Aquinas’ notion that causes can not infinitely regress. We can not comprehend infinity in it’s true extent, but there are no reasons why something can not infinitely regress. By a similar notion, this suggests that God could have been a cause given God has a cause that which can indeed infinitely regress. However, on the subject of the contingency, I do agree that given our understanding of the universe, we must be able to comprehend the concept that there must never have been a time of nothing because nothing can not spontaneously become something without a cause (nor be its own cause).

“The claim could be made that God has a “higher morality” by which his actions are to be judged. But it is a strange “higher morality” which claims that what we call “bad” is good and what we call “good” is bad.”

On the subject of evil I disagree with the text’s assumption that God’s “Higher Morality” “has no meaning to us.” Given that God exists and that he has a grasp of “higher morality”, it may have limited meaning to us but not no meaning. Because we can never know destiny or time beyond our own, the text may assume that on large scales some grand plan of morality may not have effect on us, however, that does not mean we can not try to conceptualize it as so. 

Teleological does not make sense, why would something that appear too designed actually be? Statistically with enough repetitions anything can emerge. I do not think this follows because it relies on an human inability to comprehend large numbers. This argument makes sense before we knew how large the universe is, and thus how small a statistical blip we are.

items.full_text:
# My Philosophy 07-22
2022-07-24

## **My Take**
Abstract Platonism = There is a metaphysical world of forms we will never see but still must interact with and create clarity of, increase resolution. The divine realm where ideals metaphysically exist. 

Two Level Utilitarianism (Act + Rule) = Intuition (Rule) and Critical Thought (Act) Life is sometimes too complex for a critical take on it, which is were rule utilitarianism, or intuition, comes in

Motive Utilitarianism = Create Motives that Lead to actions wherein Maximum Potential Utility is Derived such that overall contentedness is maximized. Do actives which manifest in many common domains such that your skillset is specific and yet adaptive to yet unseen hidden variables and uses.

Sartre (maybe)

Hegel / Philosophic History

Camus / Christian Existentialism

Soren Kierkegaard / The Aesthetic, Ethical, and Re

Henry David Thoreau

## **Definitions**

A deeply rational School of Thought, Platonism seeks to examine and explore above all else. Although we may not reach the answers in this life a Platonist believes they are still out there.

Some[[_who?_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] commentators hold that Plato argued that [truth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth) is an abstraction. In other words, we are urged to believe that [Plato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plato)'s theory of ideals is an [abstraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstraction), divorced from the so-called external world, of modern European philosophy, despite the fact Plato taught that ideals are ultimately real, and different from non-ideal things—indeed, he argued for a distinction between the ideal and non-ideal realm.

Motive Utilitarianism states that our initial moral task is to inculcate motives within ourselves (by means of teaching and repetition) that will be generally useful across the spectrum of the actual situations we are likely to encounter, rather than hypothetical examples which are unlikely to occur. It can be thought of as a hybrid between Act and Rule Utilitarianism, but it also attempts to take into account how human beings actually function psychologically.

Two-Level Utilitarianism states that normally we should use "intuitive" moral thinking, in the form of Rule Utilitarianism, because it usually maximizes happiness. However, there are some times when we must ascend to a higher "critical" level of reflection in order to decide what to do, and must think as an Act Utilitarian would. This method is based on the view that, although Act Utilitarianism may be preferable in theory, usually it is too difficult to perfectly predict consequences, and so we require moral guidelines or rules in day to day life.

# Stoics
#philosophy 

Modern Stoicism arose as part of the late 20th century surge of interest in [virtue ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtue_ethics). "The [...] work by philosophers like [Philippa Foot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippa_Foot), [Alasdair MacIntyre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alasdair_MacIntyre), and [Martha Nussbaum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Nussbaum), among others, have brought back virtue ethics as a viable alternative to the dominant [Kantian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantian_ethics)–[deontological](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deontological_ethics) and [utilitarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism)–[consequentialist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequentialism) approaches."[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-PigliucciIEP-2)

The Development of [Virtue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtue) [happens through] the Perfection of Agency,"[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-Becker-5) or through the "ideal agency"[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-Becker-5) as he calls it. This can be described as the belief in the "inherent primacy of virtue in terms of maximization of one's agency".[[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-PigliucciIEP-2)

Becker, for instance, points out that the whole idea of the dichotomy is in fact a major oversimplification. As he puts it, "[the] distinction between things that are within our control, or 'up to us', and those who are not [...] [is] misleading."[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-Becker-5) Instead, he proposes to read it along the lines of "it is wise to calibrate the strength, depth, and dissemination of our attachments to the fragility and transience of the objects involved."[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-Becker-5)

Irvine argues that "[w]e can restate Epictetus's dichotomy as follows: There are things over which we have complete control and things over which we have no control at all" as well as suggesting that "the dichotomy is a false dichotomy, since it ignores the existence of things over which we have some but not complete control."[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-:1-27) Pigliucci describes it as follows: "some things are up to us (chiefly, our judgments and actions), some things are not up to us (major historical events, natural phenomena), but on a number of other things we have partial control. Irvine recasts the third category in terms of internalized goals, which makes more sense of the original dichotomy."[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-PigliucciIEP-2)

I would say we have no absolute agency in the universe however we have “apparent agency” which exists to the degree that we believe it does and to the degree that we express it. Ergo, we must 

Irvine takes a more modest stance and he proposes a program of "voluntary discomfort". As he describes it: "By undertaking acts of voluntary discomfort – by, for example, choosing to be cold and hungry when we could be warm and well fed – we harden ourselves against misfortunes that might befell us in the future. If all we know is comfort, we might be traumatized when we are forced to experience pain or discomfort, as we someday almost surely will. In other words, voluntary discomfort can be thought of as a kind of vaccine: By exposing ourselves to a small amount of a weakened virus now, we create in ourselves an immunity that will protect us from a debilitating illness in the future."[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Stoicism#cite_note-:1-27)

In Stoicism, it is our interpretation of events that causes us to be happy or unhappy, not any intrinsic quality of the events. That’s why it’s so important to not be a mere reaction to outside events, because otherwise someone may feel as though life is treating them unfairly and they could have exercised the

The No Conspiracy Condition

I am a moral / genetic egoist, and believe a moral agent ought to act within his own self interest. However, what this theory seems to strain out is the conception that an individual can never be truly aware of how his actions may benefit his well being. Therefore, Utilitarianism, looking at increasing the greater utility of all, is what I must rest at. Altruism is a valuable concept to the degree that it provides the individual with a sense of well being. 
You need a balancing force of culture or regulatory bodies to balance out the rational actors self interest.

Go to work everyday

Still inaccessible because of landmines

"I act as if god exists" Jordan Peterson

O Brien in the things they carried

What it felt like to be there requires an inaccurate portrayal of truth to fully convey

"I act as if god exists"

What is pragmatic is not always true. The valuable insight that the Bible contains is based on a lie, that of God and all further extrapolations, to present a valid and believable system for pre scientific man. Now we must transition those psychological values 

All warfare is deception

All business is warfare

Life as actions rather than objects

We are now gods but for the wisdom

## PRAGMATISM NOTES

As fun as it is to delve, adventurous and gainly, one can dig too deep. Forbidden knowledge is the antimatter of the sacred. 

Is Truth Good?

No, not always. Truth is good up until the point it is not. One must untangle the mess of their mind to understand their true goals and their (subsequent) rational goals. 

Yes you are a receptor of sense data but you choose what to focus on

People complain about themselves


Scientists show how, artists show why

POEM - WHO YOU ARE
You are not who you are 
You are not who you were
You are not what you've become 
You are what you are becoming

POEM-  A LIFE HALF REMEMBERED
Without heart heaven harbor 
Hope of death becomes respite
only to be a shallow shelter 
when death not remain 

And life then
only half remembered 
And only half lived 
becomes a stone 
with no word but a name

POEM - JULY 21, 2015
I wallow in darkness
My very high brow is no longer a boon
My self is not but a shell
of meaningless butter
Golden boy, Golden Child
those diabetes at every turn
Yet the fat clamor for more butter

Don't they see?
I am an unhealthy delight
Just buy I can't Believe Its Not Butter
It a better butter but

Chemicals burn in.

I'm a milkman with a leaky tire
It can tread along
not knowing when i will have use the car jack

I tire of the tire
That inhibits my growth
the growth of my decay

I'm an equation of antiquation
An equilibrium of chaos
The probability of my actions 
Is Hardy and predictable

But the results are far more amusing.

items.full_text:
# AI is Hard
#article #paper-review
2022-08-04

[https://arxiv.org/pdf/2104.12871.pdf](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2104.12871.pdf)

_"In 1960 Herbert Simon declared that, “Machines will be capable, within twenty years, of doing any work that a man can do” [10]. The following year, Claude Shannon echoed this prediction: “I confidently expect that within a matter of 10 or 15 years, something will emerge from the laboratory which is not too far from the robot of science fiction fame” [11]. And a few years later Marvin Minsky forecast that, “Within a generation...the problems of creating ‘artificial intelligence’ will be substantially solved” [12]. "_

-   There are "AI Winters" and "AI Springs"

-   Perceptron 
-   80s Expert Systems - not generalizable collections of human experts
-   90s-2000s - machine learning 
-   2010s - deep learning and neural nets

-   Fallacies 

-   **First Step Fallacy** (+ Linear Development Fallacy) (~Monkey climbing a tree is a first step to getting on the moon~)
-   **Things That Are Easy are Easy Fallacy**

-   _"This is a form of what’s been called “Moravec’s paradox,” named after roboticist Hans Moravec, who wrote, “It is comparatively easy to make computers exhibit adult level performance on intelligence tests or playing checkers, and difficult or impossible to give them the skills of a one-year-old when it comes to perception and mobility” "_
-   _“Encoded in the large, highly evolved sensory and motor portions of the human brain is a billion years of experience about the nature of the world and how to survive in it. The deliberate process we call reasoning is, I believe, the thinnest veneer of human thought, effective only because it is supported by this much older and much more powerful, though usually unconscious, sensorimotor knowledge. We are all prodigious Olympians in perceptual and motor areas, so good that we make the difficult look easy” [44]._
-   Or more succinctly, Marvin Minsky notes, “In general, we’re least aware of what our minds do best” 

-   Intelligence is all in the Brain Fallacy

-   information-processing model of mind (psychology, mid century)
-   Leads to natural assumption that we can copy our brain onto computers or remove brain in a new body 
-   _"Today’s deep neural networks are akin to the proverbial brain-in-a-vat: passively taking in data from the world and outputting instructions for behavior without actively interacting in the world with any kind of body. "_
-   _"Geoffrey Hinton predicted, “To understand [documents] at a human level, we’re probably going to need human-level resources and we have trillions of connections [in our brains]. ...But the biggest networks we have built so far only have billions of connections. So we’re a few orders of magnitude off, but I’m sure the hardware people will fix that” [63]. "_

  

_"Indeed, several researchers have made analogies between AI and the medieval practice of alchemy. In 1977, AI researcher Terry Winograd wrote, “In some ways [AI] is akin to medieval alchemy. We are at the stage of pouring together different combinations of substances and seeing what happens, not yet having developed satisfactory theories...but...it was the practical experience and curiosity of the alchemists which provided the wealth of data from which a scientific theory of chemistry could be developed” [85]. Four decades later, Eric Horvitz, director of Microsoft Research, concurred: “Right now, what we are doing is not a science but a kind of alchemy” [86]. In order to understand the nature of true progress in AI, and in particular, why it is harder than we think, we need to move from alchemy to developing a scientific understanding of intelligence."_

  

From **Douglass Hofstadter, Boolean Dream**

"The problem of intelligence, as I see it, is to understand the fluid nature of mental categories . . . To emphasize this and make the point as starkly as I can, I hereby make the following claim: The central problem of AI is the question: What is

# Chinese Mosques
#history 
2022-03-20

The Zhenghai Mosque in Ningbo city, Zhejiang province is a type of Islamic Architecture which appeared in China during the Song dynasty (990 AD). When the Arabic traders arrived at the big commercial city of Ningbo and settled down there, they spread the Muslim culture and built a mosque. Later, more mosques were built around Beijing.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-45)[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-46) The case itself is found in the mosques of Xi'an such as Xi'an Great Mosque and Daxuexi Alley Mosque.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-:0-47) Beijing's Mosques also follow essentially the norms of Chinese planning,[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-48) layout, design, and traditional wooden structure.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-:0-47)[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-49)[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_architecture#cite_note-50)

items.full_text:
# Thomas Edison Concrete Houses
**WHY DOLORES CHUMSKY HATES THOMAS EDISON**
2021-11-01

[Thomas Edison's Concrete Houses](http://flyingmoose.org/truthfic/edison.htm)

**By Adam Goodheart**

Dolores Chumsky's house leaks. There's no way to fix it. "Just try and get someone to come and make repairs," laments the Union, N.J., resident. "They may come in once, but they never come back."

That's because Chumsky's innocent-looking suburban residence is a handyman's nightmare. It also stands as a monument to one of the most colossal flops in the history of scientific innovation. It is one of a dozen surviving examples of Thomas Edison's worst invention ever: the single-piece cast-concrete house.

Edison's concrete houses aren't quite as well-known as, say, the incandescent bulb, the phonograph, or the motion picture. Yet the great inventor devoted nearly as much time and effort to them as he did to any of his better-known discoveries. He even dreamt of a future in which millions of Americans would not only live in concrete houses, but also sleep on concrete beds, and play music on concrete pianos.

It was a classic case of one failure begetting another. In the late 1880s, Edison had turned to perfecting a new process for refining iron ore using magnets and massive crushing rollers. The enterprise wasted more than a decade of effort and several million dollars. But instead of selling the equipment for scrap and calling it a day, the redoubtable Edison decided to use the huge rollers to manufacture high-grade cement.

![[Pasted image 20220317183137.png]]

By 1906, four years after its opening, the cement plant, too, had become a money pit. But if no one wanted his cement, the Wizard of Menlo Park declared, he would create his own demand.

That August, in an after-dinner speech in New York City, Edison announced his latest brainchild to the world. Concrete homes, he said, would revolutionize American life. They would be fireproof, insect-proof, easy to clean. The walls could be pre-tinted in attractive colors and would never need to be repainted. Everything from shingles to bathtubs to picture frames would be cast as a single monolith of concrete, in a process that took just a few hours. Extra stories could be added with a simple adjustment of the molding forms. Best of all, the $1,200-dollar houses would be cheap enough for even the poorest slum-dwellers to afford.

Scarcely less extravagant were the claims of Edison's admirers. "The time will most certainly come when whole houses will be turned out in one piece," a biographer declared in 1907. When the molds were removed, he wrote, "a solid and almost bomb-proof house will be left behind."
![[Pasted image 20220317183149.png]]
Because New Jersey has not yet been subjected to extensive bombardment, the veracity of that statement is hard to test. In nearly every other respect, however, Edison's early prototypes proved disastrous. Instead of simple molds, the houses required nickel-plated iron forms containing more than two thousand parts and weighing nearly half a million pounds. A builder had to buy at least $175,000 in equipment before pouring a single house. Furthermore, nobody wanted to live in a residence that had been dubbed "the salvation of the slum dweller." Although Edison optimistically described an early model as "in the style of Francois I," it was more in the style of an oversized outhouse.

Undaunted, Edison announced that he was generously turning his invention over, free, to anyone who wanted to help humanity. Building contractors didn't exactly beat a path to his door. So in 1911, the inventor made another go of it. This time, he announced, he had discovered a product line for which concrete was ideally suited: home furnishings.

Using special lightweight "foam concrete," Edison proposed the manufacture of concrete phonograph cabinets and concrete pianos. Concrete bedroom sets -- more durable and beautiful than those "in the most palatial residence in Paris or along the

# Blue and White Pottery Kraak
#pottery #history #china #holland #middle-east #japan

Blue and white export porcelain was beloved in Europe and the Islamic world. When the Ming->Qing transition happened production was decreased and the dutch started copying to a greater degree (the copying started with Medici-ware, but via the Dutch VOC restarted en masse as Kraak ware and Delftware (unclear difference))

its frankly hilarious in the grand scheme of things that people are mad about china stealing western technology

_"Some blue and white wares of the 16th century were characterized by Islamic influences, such as the ware under the Zhengde Emperor (1506–1521), which sometimes bore Persian and Arabic script,[12] due to the influence of Muslim eunuchs serving at his court."_

_"In the 18th century export porcelain continued to be produced for the European markets.[12] Partly as a result of the work of Francois Xavier d'Entrecolles however, an early example of industrial spying in which the details of Chinese porcelain manufacture were transmitted to Europe, Chinese exports of porcelain soon shrank considerably, especially by the end of the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.[14]"_

_"In 1654 a gunpowder explosion in Delft destroyed many breweries and as the brewing industry was in decline, they became available to pottery makers looking for larger premises; some retained the old brewery names, e.g. The Double Tankard, The Young Moors' Head, and The Three Bells.[6]"_

_"Influential_ [_tea masters_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schools_of_Japanese_tea) _praised the rough, spontaneous,_ [_wabi-sabi_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wabi-sabi)_, appearance of Japanese rural wares, mostly stoneware, over the perfection of Chinese-inspired porcelain made by highly-skilled specialists."_

items.full_text:
# Red Dawn
#media #clip 
2022-03-12

[The United States Stands Alone: A Review of “Red Dawn” (1984) – NAOC](https://natoassociation.ca/the-united-states-stands-alone-a-review-of-red-dawn-1984/)
Via Rob Ager of [[Collative Learning]]

The salient theme running through _Red Dawn_ is the tension that exists between the desirability of childlike innocence and the danger it poses to the one blessed with it. In effect, innocence breeds complacency and becomes the agent of its own destruction. It makes the indulgent vulnerable to their enemies, unaware of what is at stake. Only after innocence is overcome can it be regained and passed on to future generations. The generations that fought the two World Wars and then the Cold War lost their innocence so that subsequent generations could retain theirs. Paradoxically, a generation with no knowledge of war, with its innocence intact, might not appreciate what it has. ‘Freedom isn’t free,’ is the resounding message of _Red Dawn_. The cost of freedom requires the periodic sacrificing of childlike innocence, at both the personal and collective level, and the cultivation of a sense of responsibility and vigilant defense of what one has. Otherwise, one will be left lamenting, like Jed and Matt’s father from behind the internment camp fence, “One way or another…for one reason or another…we’re all gone…it’s all gone.”

items.full_text:
# Home Notes
#home #plumbing #structural #architecture #climate-control #earthquake #electrical
2021-11-05

## Plumbing
"We are living in a renaissance after a dark ages that emerged in the industrial era. A dark age in which people forsook their ancient crafts, and forgot how to make."

  ![[Pasted image 20220317185448.png]]

-   **EARTHQUAKE PROTECTION** 

-   Bolts from mudsill into foundation 

-   Really REALLY large washers to distribute load, "mudsill plates" also have teeth that dig into mud sill
-   Hole in mud sill should not be larger than bolt, can cause cracking

-   Diagonal Bracing on cripple walls
-   Plywood / OSB on cripple walls as bracing (drilled with holes for ventilation
-   Extra framing lumber between studs of cripple wall along base (blocking)

-   Allows use of screws
-   Flush cut (where shear plywood is not sitting on the mud sill so it can be nailed into the mud sill 
-   Blocking can also be achieved by staples 

-   Steel **Joist Shear transfer** tie on joist and wall 
-   [https://bayarearetrofit.com/san-francisco-soft-story-retrofit-contractors-and-engineers/](https://bayarearetrofit.com/san-francisco-soft-story-retrofit-contractors-and-engineers/) Postulates that stucco is better at eartquake resistance than wood panelling
-   **Sheer transfer ties** for bracing between top of cripple wall and end joist
-   **Tie down** between sheer wall stud and foundation

-   **ENTRYWAY**

-   Easy to sweep off ledge (stairs going downward or ledge)
-   Wooden floor is entirely flat, probably fake wood for durability
-   Wall integrated shoe storage
-   **DOOR**

-   Door should be heavy wood with metal bracing, small window or metal frame single pane window (resist rams), with ability to be boarded up (nailed to, or build in interior shutters)
-   Paintable 
-   Removable panel to signal denomination or family crest or similar, bas relief

-   Have small tabernacle / shrine area near doorbell
