items.full_text:
# Hauntology, Mallwave, Bladerunner

2021-11-21

[D.I.Y tuning - Vangelis - Blade Runner Blues 432Hz ( 回聲增幅+音場延伸Echo increase+Sound field extension) - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XB8EAWKXHsw)

Anemoia 

This generation in particular seems to have a nostalgia for a past they never lived. Something about the 90s and 80s zeitgeist, its aesthetics, its vibe, its qualities as viewed through the lens of old cassette tapes, syndicated shows, and media, filtered through the lens of the late 90s and early 2000s media. Goodwill and Salvation Army, used CD racks. Old PC games that we never could play. An era enabled by the surge in VHS content derived from the past 20 years of content to fill the burgeoning market. 

A comment I saw on a sound field expanded Vangelis score of Bladerunner video on YouTube expressed the sentiment he shared with the replicants, that of a memory, a nostalgic past, that we may have never lived. A mythical past imagined, that we can't quite equate with something we ever truly experienced firsthand. In a similar vein, mall wave is a series of empty malls with distorted 90s elevator Muzac, similar to vaporware in many respects which takes the Simpsons and does a similar distortion. 

Terms to look into: 

 Lost Futures, 

  

Hauntology - Derida -> our current experience is haunted by memories of the past and imaginings of the future

  

Mark Fisher Cultural Theory -> Cultural Hauntology -> We try to go into the past to relive the potential futures

  

Digital worlds do not "decay" in the same way as the physical world and therefore can not make way for new forms 

  

Liminal Space - temporary spaces like hallways -> create off-putting feelings when being stuck in a place that's supposed to have life or only supposed to be temporary, when its purpose is lost 

  

This is why I felt so creeped out going to model homes at the Amish Town or the disembodies voices at Filoli Mansion

  

Linear movement of history is the product result of the enlightenment development 

  

Other cultures who didn't expiernce the industrial revolution or the long death of Rome would not have a similar feel. China for instance had a more slow development but never a "dark age"

  

"Instead of changing the world, we deconstruct it"

  

Macintosh + is no more real than the music its using 

  

Post truth is postmodern 

  

  

Adam Neely -> harmonic analysis starts to break down, not its about contextual analysis 

  

Vaporware is the same kind of modern art that is about the recontextualization of something, in this case old art

  

_"The whole appeal of vaporwave is its use of 'remaining unknown', where in a world where nothing is [hidden], it is refreshing to find something that feels like it was found in the dumpster of a thrift shop, where it does not matter where it comes from or who made it, only that it takes you elsewhere, somewhere distant, from reality."_

-   Ecovirtual

  

  

What is scream rap?

  

  

City pop takes Japanese 80s economic and technological future optimism 

  

"With the Jackson 5 and your anime girlfriend cheering you on"

  

Farside virtual genre -> the utopianism of sims the simcity and ringtones 

  

Raves being in "abandoned factories and warehouses" is inherently part of the appeal

items.full_text:
# Human Experimentation, United States
#history/modern #war #war/cold-war

2021-11-25

In 1989, a British study of Unit 731 strongly supported the theory of United States–Japanese biological warfare culpability in Korea.[8]

Until the end of World War II, Japan operated a covert biological and chemical warfare research and development unit called Unit 731 in Harbin (now China). The unit's activities, including human experimentation, were documented by the Khabarovsk War Crime Trials conducted by the Soviet Union in December 1949. However, at that time, the US government described the Khabarovsk trials as "vicious and unfounded propaganda".[1] It was later revealed that the accusations made against the Japanese military were correct. The US government had taken over the research at the end of the war and had then covered up the program.[2] Leaders of Unit 731 were exempted from war crimes prosecution by the United States and then placed on the payroll of the US.[3]

A classified report entitled "Psychochemical Warfare: A New Concept of War" was produced in 1949 by Luther Wilson Greene, Technical Director of the Chemical and Radiological Laboratories at Edgewood. Greene called for a search for novel psychoactive compounds that would create the same debilitating mental side effects as those produced by nerve gases, but without their lethal effect. In his words, Throughout recorded history, wars have been characterized by death, human misery, and the destruction of property; each major conflict being more catastrophic than the one preceding it…I am convinced that it is possible, by means of the techniques of psychochemical warfare, to conquer an enemy without the wholesale killing of his people or the mass destruction of his property.[2]

Facetime Technical -> Uses Apple Push Notifications Service to initiate, then a p2p connection, where identity certificates are checked, and a
items.full_text:
# How Facetime Works
#software-engineering #flashcards 

Facetime Technical -> Uses Apple Push Notifications Service to initiate, then a p2p connection, where identity certificates are checked, and a shared key is created for the session. Each devices [[Nonce]] is "are combined to salt keys for each of the media channels, which are streamed via Secure Real Time Protocol (SRTP)"

_“FaceTime is Apple’s video and audio calling service. Similar to iMessage, FaceTime calls also use the Apple Push Notification service to establish an initial connection to the user’s registered devices. The audio/video contents of FaceTime calls are protected by end-to-end encryption, so no one but the sender and receiver can access them. Apple cannot decrypt the data._

_FaceTime uses Internet Connectivity Establishment (ICE) to establish a peer-to-peer connection between devices. Using Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) messages, the devices verify their identity certificates and establish a shared secret for each session. The cryptographic nonces supplied by each device are combined to salt keys for each of the media channels, which are streamed via Secure Real Time Protocol (SRTP) using AES-256 encryption.“_

items.full_text:
# Nonce
#flashcards 
Nonce -> Number, Once. Is an arbitrary number used in cryptography. In the spirit of a [Nonce word - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonce_word) which is a word created ad hoc for a specific purpose. 

Nonces are also used in [Proof-Of-Work] to make it harder to 'cheese' the hash. 

For example, proof of work, using hash functions, was considered as a means to combat [email spam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email_spam "Email spam") by forcing email senders to find a hash value for the email (which included a timestamp to prevent pre-computation of useful hashes for later use) that had an arbitrary number of leading zeroes, by hashing the same input with a large number of values until a "desirable" hash was obtained.

items.full_text:
# Phone Dials 
2022-01-24
#ux 

*"As is often the cause with advances in technology, the government wanted to get involved and asked that the phone dial be adapted for special services. The result was the Autovon phone system, used only by the Department of Defense and the White House. In this system the keys A through D were used to signal a call’s priority to the government’s PBX network: Flash Override (A), Flash (B), Immediate (C), and Priority (D), with Flash Override being the highest.*

 *Pressing one of these keys before you dialed your number gave your call priority over other conversations on the network. For example, pressing C, Immediate, before dialing would make the switch first look for any free lines. If all lines were in use, the switch would disconnect any non-priority calls, and then any Priority (D) calls. The A key, Flash Override, would kick every other call off the trunks between the origin and destination."*

items.full_text:
# Timex Watches History
2022-01-20

**Slogan: World's largest manufacturer of watches and mechanical time fuses

Navy [_Terrier_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RIM-2_Terrier) missile is controlled in flight through the stabilization system, provided by the U.S. Time–manufactured gyro

Timex manufactured mechanical components for missiles during the boom of American missile development in the late 1950s, including fuses, gyroscope, [accelerometers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accelerometer), guidance sub-system, and various other miniature precision items.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timex_Group_USA#cite_note-20) The company promoted its products under the claim of being the "_world's largest manufacturer of watches and mechanical time fuses_."[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timex_Group_USA#cite_note-21)

The company also produced ammunition components, and repaired, installed, and reactivated government-owned production equipment. The height of the company's ordnance and ammunition business lasted through the Vietnam era in the 1960s and 1970s, during which it operated [Joliet Army Ammunition Plant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joliet_Army_Ammunition_Plant)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timex_Group_USA#cite_note-22) as well as privately owned plants and storage facilities.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timex_Group_USA#cite_note-23)

items.full_text:
# 153 W1 LEC 1
- "Groupware"
- CSCW Started as individual - human factors research
- Added organizational 
- Added teams (1994, Grudin)
- Early CSCW Failures - except email 
	- Grudin 1988 - "Why CSCW applications fail"
	- Okamura 1993 "Helping CSCS Apps Succeed"
- Grudin 1988 - "Why CSCW applications fail"
	- Developers do not understand social dynamics 
	- Management has less stake in groupware as opposed to institutional technology 
	- Harder to get adoption than single user systems
	- Smaller applications must fit organizational context
- **Challenges** - Grudin 1988 - "Why CSCW applications fail"  
	- Disparity between Work and Benefit
		- Can add additional work to some team members // Jocko failure to communicate "Why"
	- Critical Mass
		- All group members must adopt system to benefit
		- Ex. Electronic bulletin board didn't get used until someone wanted to sell a bag // network effect
	- Socio-political factors 
		- Single users systems can change organizations 
		- Organizational systems - people adapt 
		- Ex. Automatic scheduling system failed because normally people don't put incidental tasks on calendar (social norm) - people eventually filled up their calendars 
	- Exception handling 
		- Step by step linear flow is less likely in group work
		- // Effective groupware requires Talebian optionality 
	- Integrating infrequently used features user differences 
		- Must be accessible but also minimal
	- Difficult to evaluate groupware (lots of variables) 
		- // Seems like something that is a problem for the market to solve
	- Wrong Intuitions 
		- Relying on individual software intuitions that may not translate to groupware 
		- Decision makers often only look at a subset of users, often work for other subsets is mis-estimated
	- Manage acceptance

# US vs CHINA in Africa

- China has potential economic incentives to invest in Africa (resource extraction, market seeking, military-political power)
- Chinese trade with Africa is growing significantly 
- US interests are mostly military-political (countering china) 
- Africa aligns politically with china more than US 
- During times of strife (2008) investment in china, correlated with swayed political alignment closer to that of China 
- After peaking in 2008, US investment in Africa has gone negative by 2020
- China is holding African countries accountable vs old "no strings attach" - narrative of "loan entrapment" is becoming less applicable 
- // Africa, given the US-China military-political interest conflict, will remain unstable. However, given it's size, there may be pockets of extreme growth, like Egypt and Israel.

# Wittgenstein's Language Games
2022-03-27

Speaking languages in a context outside where the language originated sub-optimally "mixing language games" - there is also no shared measurement 

The problem is that Wittgenstein is in fact creating a language game via his extreme relativism 

Remove words from needing to be correlated to objects 
-   Then there is no need to worry about "I exist" what is I, my brain, my body, my soul?
-   Communication falters because we have differing imaginations and contexts - we have problems in communication when we don't fully understand the "game" that the other person is playing
-   Description is better than explanation 
-   Clarity > truth

// you are different people to different people

items.full_text:
# 121 Lecture 3, part 2 Pre-Work: Design Process Diagram
When faced with a design problem (not necessarily software design), what do you do?

Think through the process you follow, then create a diagram depicting that process. Upload it here.

- Outline intuitive / known possible solutions 
- Research possible solutions, in notes or online
- Synthesize research and intuitions
- 

Note: think _realistically_, not idealistically.

```mermaid
flowchart TB
	Z(Consider problem)
	A(Outline intuitive / known possible references)
	B(Research possible references, in notes or online)
	C(Meta outline all References)
	D(Synthesize from meta outline)

	Z --> A
	A --> B
	B --> C
	C --> D
	D --> A
```

# Notes from an Engineers
Richard Hamming: The Art of Doing Science and Engineering

[https://kirazhang.com/posts/science-engineering-notes-ch1](https://kirazhang.com/posts/science-engineering-notes-ch1)

[https://kirazhang.com/posts/science-engineering-notes-ch2](https://kirazhang.com/posts/science-engineering-notes-ch2)

 **those who aim to make significant contribution to humanity rather than just get along through life comfortably achieve the greatest total happiness in life** 

**one with a vision will get to a distance proportional to n, one without will only get to a distance √n** .

1.  A problem in knowledge acquisition is **the rate at which new knowledge makes the old knowledge obsolete** . The solution is to **learn fundamentals** . One can recognize fundamentals by asking:

-   Have they lasted for a long time?
-   Can we derive other knowledge in the field from these using standard methods in the field?

1.  Get in the habit of **quick modeling to check quantitative remarks** .

-   You will more likely retain the results having done the calculation yourself.
-   Practice making calculations and quick modeling prepare you to do the same on more important applications.

1.  Computers are changing the way organizations operate and decision-making process are determined. One example is computers gave top managements the power to micromanage their organization. Top managements have shown little ability to resist the temptation of micromanaging, yet central planning has been repeatedly shown to give poor results.

# Hackers and Painters
**HACKERS AND PAINTERS** 
**Qoutes**
```
I've never liked the term "computer science." The main reason I don't like it is that there's no such thing. Computer science is a grab
items.full_text:
# Hackers and Painters
**HACKERS AND PAINTERS** 
**Qoutes**
```
I've never liked the term "computer science." The main reason I don't like it is that there's no such thing. Computer science is a grab bag of tenuously related areas thrown together by an accident of history, like Yugoslavia. At one end you have people who are really mathematicians, but call what they're doing computer science so they can get DARPA grants. In the middle you have people working on something like the natural history of computers-- studying the behavior of algorithms for routing data through networks, for example. And then at the other extreme you have the hackers, who are trying to write interesting software, and for whom computers are just a medium of expression, as concrete is for architects or paint for painters. It's as if mathematicians, physicists, and architects all had to be in the same department. 

Sometimes what the hackers do is called "software engineering," but this term is just as misleading. Good software designers are no more engineers than architects are. The border between architecture and engineering is not sharply defined, but it's there. It falls between what and how: architects decide what to do, and engineers figure out how to do it. 

Perhaps one day "computer science" will, like Yugoslavia, get broken up into its component parts. That might be a good thing. Especially if it meant independence for my native land, hacking. 

The mathematicians don't seem bothered by this. They happily set to work proving theorems like the other mathematicians over in the math department, and probably soon stop noticing that the building they work in says \`\`computer science'' on the outside. But for the hackers this label is a problem. If what they're doing is called science, it makes them feel they ought to be acting scientific. So instead of doing what they really want to do, which is to design beautiful software, hackers in universities and research labs feel they ought to be writing research papers. 

Unfortunately, beautiful things don't always make the best subjects for papers. Number one, research must be original-- and as anyone who has written a PhD dissertation knows, the way to be sure that you're exploring virgin territory is to to stake out a piece of ground that no one wants. 

In the best case, the papers are just a formality. Hackers write cool software, and then write a paper about it, and the paper becomes a proxy for the achievement represented by the software. But often this mismatch causes problems. It's easy to drift away from building beautiful things toward building ugly things that make more suitable subjects for research papers. 

All the time I was in graduate school I had an uncomfortable feeling in the back of my mind that I ought to know more theory, and that it was very remiss of me to have forgotten all that stuff within three weeks of the final exam. 

For example, I was taught in college that one ought to figure out a program completely on paper before even going near a computer. I found that I did not program this way. I found that I liked to program sitting in front of a computer, not a piece of paper. Worse still, instead of patiently writing out a complete program and assuring myself it was correct, I tended to just spew out code that was hopelessly broken, and gradually beat it into shape. 

  

Debugging, I was taught, was a kind of final pass where you caught typos and oversights. The way I worked, it seemed like programming consisted of debugging. 

For a long time I felt bad about this, just as I once felt bad that I didn't hold my pencil the way they taught me to in elementary school. If I had only looked over at the other makers, the painters or the architects, I would have realized that there was a name for what I was doing: sketching. As far as I can tell, the way they taught me to program in college was all wrong. You should figure out programs as you're writing them, just as writers and paint

items.full_text:
# Wikipedia
**THOUGHTS ON WIKIPEDIA** 
#tertiary-sources #wikipedia #
December 2020

I really don't like the anti-wikipedia, or really, anti-tertiary source meme

  

Just because I am posting from Wikipedia, despite what your high school English teacher may have memed, does not deny the fact that Wikipedia provides a practical, crowdsourced, terse, and high level view of complex topics.

  

Encyclopedia Brittanica, which came from the Scottish Enlightenment, a movement from which names such as David Hume and Adam Smith came of, in their first edition stated "utility should be the primary intention of every publication."

  

"It is by understanding basic principles, that the non specialist ("the ordinary man") is able to practically apply what he learns."

  

Ergo, as I am not a professor of political science, nor a political candidate, nor am I a professional or academic philosopher, the use of wikipedia in reference to concept definitions, historical events, descriptions of philosophy, etc, is not only valid but pragmatic. 

  

This is especially true given that the whole point of selecting text to copy is to communicate it. By quoting wikipedia, I can provide a quote which is terse, high level, and easily digestible. 

  

Given all the hullaballoo about "I cant read a paragraph durh", I would think qouting wikipedia is actually exactly what such a person would want

  

I'll wager in ordinary life, outside of a career, a comprehensive view is much more useful that a narrow one. 

  

I could attempt to read articles outside my knowledge wheelhouse from "firsthand sources" and attempt to comprehend (if not, in all likelyhood, barely comprehend). 

  

Or I can get a survey view and actually have some basis of fundamental principles. 

\------------------------------------------------

the whole "tertiary source bad, firsthand source good" is prescribed on the basis that in the academic use-case, knowledge must be traceable and therefore verifiable, or at the very least, attributable

  

I would not regale you with the single definition of the concept I know from Nassim Talebs's reading of Descartes. Unless I was read on multiple authors interpretation of the concept, I would want to have read, and be able to share, a larger sample size of definitions, if not the definition, with qoutes from many authors, from Wikipedia.

items.full_text:
# The Book of my Enemy Has Been Remaindered

**## The Book of my Enemy Has Been Remaindered**
Clive James (1939- )
The book of my enemy has been remaindered
And I am pleased.
In vast quantities it has been remaindered
Like a van-load of counterfeit that has been seized
And sits in piles in a police warehouse,
My enemy's much-prized effort sits in piles
In the kind of bookshop where remaindering occurs.
Great, square stacks of rejected books and, between them, aisles
One passes down reflecting on life's vanities,
Pausing to remember all those thoughtful reviews
Lavished to no avail upon one's enemy's book --
For behold, here is that book
Among these ranks and banks of duds,
These ponderous and seemingly irreducible cairns
Of complete stiffs.

The book of my enemy has been remaindered
And I rejoice.
It has gone with bowed head like a defeated legion
Beneath the yoke.
What avail him now his awards and prizes,
The praise expended upon his meticulous technique,
His individual new voice?
Knocked into the middle of next week
His brainchild now consorts with the bad buys
The sinker, clinkers, dogs and dregs,
The Edsels of the world of moveable type,
The bummers that no amount of hype could shift,
The unbudgeable turkeys.

Yea, his slim volume with its understated wrapper
Bathes in the blare of the brightly jacketed Hitler's War Machine,
His unmistakably individual new voice
Shares the same scrapyard with a forlorn skyscraper 
Of The Kung-Fu Cookbook,
His honesty, proclaimed by himself and believed by others,
His renowned abhorrence of all posturing and pretense,
Is there with Pertwee's Promenades and Pierrots--
One Hundred Years of Seaside Entertainment,
And (oh, this above all) his sensibility,
His sensibility and its hair-like filaments,
His delicate, quivering sensibility is now as one
With Barbara Windsor's Book of Boobs,
A volume graced by the descriptive rubric
"My boobs will give everyone hours of fun".

Soon now a book of mine could be remaindered also,
Though not to the monumental extent
In which the chastisement of remaindering has been meted out
To the book of my enemy,
Since in the case of my own book it will be due
To a miscalculated print run, a marketing error--
Nothing to do with merit.
But just supposing that such an event should hold
Some slight element of sadness, it will be offset
By the memory of this sweet moment.
Chill the champagne and polish the crystal goblets! 
The book of my enemy has been remaindered
And I am glad.

Via Paul Dourish

items.full_text:
# Jesus Market Temple
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleansing_of_the_Temple#Analysis

Professor David Landry of the University of St. Thomas suggests that "the importance of the episode is signaled by the fact that within a week of this incident, Jesus is dead. Matthew, Mark, and Luke agree that this is the event that functioned as the 'trigger' for Jesus' death."[15]

Butler University professor James F. McGrath explains that the animal sales were related to selling animals for use in the animal sacrifices in the Temple. He also explains that the moneychangers in the temple existed to convert the many currencies in use into the accepted currency for paying the Temple taxes.[16] E. P. Sanders and Bart Ehrman say that Greek and Roman currency was converted to Jewish and Tyrian money.[2][17]

A common interpretation is that Jesus was reacting to the practice of money changers routinely cheating the people, but Marvin L. Krier Mich observes that a good deal of money was stored at the temple, where it could be loaned by the wealthy to the poor who were in danger of losing their land to debt. The Temple establishment therefore co-operated with the aristocracy in the exploitation of the poor. One of the first acts of the First Jewish-Roman War was the burning of the debt records in the archives.[18]

Pope Francis sees the Cleansing of the Temple not as a violent act but more of a prophetic demonstration.[19] In addition to writing and speaking messages from God, Israelite or Jewish *nevi'im* ("spokespersons", "prophets") often acted out prophetic actions in their life.[20][*page needed*]

According to D.A. Carson, the fact that Jesus was not arrested by the Temple guards was due to the fact that the crowd supported Jesus's actions.[21] Maurice Casey agrees with this view, stating that Temple's authorities were probably afraid that sending guards against Jesus and his disciples would cause a revolt and a carnage, while Roman soldiers in the Antonia Fortress did not feel the need to act for a minor disturbance such as this; however, Jesus's actions probably prompted the authorities' decision to have Jesus arrested some days later and later had him crucified by Roman prefect Pontius Pilate.[22]

items.full_text:
# To an Athlete Dying Young

**## To an Athlete Dying Young**## 

BY _A. E. HOUSMAN_

The time you won your town the race
We chaired you through the market-place;
Man and boy stood cheering by,
And home we brought you shoulder-high.

Today, the road all runners come,
Shoulder-high we bring you home,
And set you at your threshold down,
Townsman of a stiller town.

Smart lad, to slip betimes away
From fields where glory does not stay,
And early though the laurel grows
It withers quicker than the rose.

Eyes the shady night has shut
Cannot see the record cut,
And silence sounds no worse than cheers
After earth has stopped the ears.

Now you will not swell the rout
Of lads that wore their honours out,
Runners whom renown outran
And the name died before the man.

So set, before its echoes fade,
The fleet foot on the sill of shade,
And hold to the low lintel up
The still-defended challenge-cup.

And round that early-laurelled head
Will flock to gaze the strengthless dead,
And find unwithered on its curls
The garland briefer than a girl’s.

items.full_text:
# Eugenics 
https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/eugenics/

Some philosophers think they can be distinguished, and they have explored the desirability of a “liberal” or “new” as opposed to an “authoritarian” or “old” eugenics (Agar 2004). Liberal eugenics would be based upon prospective parents’ free choice, pluralist values, and up-to-date scientific understanding of genomic science and technology. Furthermore, advocates of liberal eugenics aim to be sensitive to the effects of some problematic but deeply entrenched social problems (e.g., racism, sexism, heterosexism) on individual choice. Authoritarian eugenics programs, in contrast, were coercive state programs designed to promote social goods, and were based on problematic scientific assumptions about hereditability.

# Nazi Labor Unions

Nazi Labor Unions

March 20 2023
_https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Labour_Front_

_https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strength_Through_Joy_

_https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Socialist_League_of_the_Reich_for_Physical_Exercise_

As early as March 1933, two months after Hitler was appointed Chancellor, the Sturmabteilung began to attack trade union offices without legal consequences. Several union offices were occupied, their furnishings were destroyed, their documents were stolen or burned, and union members were beaten and in some cases killed; the police ignored these attacks and declared itself without jurisdiction.[2] These early attacks occurred at random, carried out spontaneously by rank-and-file Nazis motivated by a desire to destroy "Marxism",[3] and the Nazi Party leadership only implemented a general policy in May. On 2 May, 1933, trade union headquarters throughout Germany were occupied, their funds were confiscated, and the unions were officially abolished and their leaders arrested.[4] Many union leaders were beaten and sent to concentration camps, including some who had previously agreed to cooperate with the Nazis.[4]

Three weeks later, Hitler issued a decree that banned collective bargaining and stated that a group of labour trustees, appointed by him, would "regulate labour contracts" and maintain "labour peace."[6]

This decree effectively outlawed strikes, since workers could not oppose the decisions of the trustees.[6] Meanwhile, Robert Ley promised "to restore absolute leadership to the natural leader of a factory – that is, the employer... Only the employer can decide."[6]

Under supervision of the National Socialist League of the Reich for Physical Exercise, by 1936 sports and physical training were implemented in factories, and employees under the age of 18 were required to spend time in their workweek performing exercise. The Sports Office also pushed employers to build recreation facilities on work grounds, such as tennis courts, and offered tax incentives as encouragement.

Its all super interesting 
they basically raid and seize the unions and make it state controlled
keep wages low to boost rearmament
but also vouch for clean, low noise, ventilated work places, subsidized vacation programs, with the intended side effect of a physically fit populace who can be tooled for war
and also create meaning for people by community building between classes

items.full_text:
# Human echolocation is a learned ability for humans to sense their…

Human echolocation is a learned ability for humans to sense their environment from echoes. This ability is used by some blind people to navigate their environment and sense their surroundings in detail. Studies in 2010[115] and 2011[116] using functional magnetic resonance imaging techniques have shown that parts of the brain associated with visual processing are adapted for the new skill of echolocation. Studies with blind patients, for example, suggest that the click-echoes heard by these patients were processed by brain regions devoted to vision rather than audition.[116]

_https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_echolocation_

items.full_text:
# AR vBus Stops

AR vBus Stops
May 12 2023

Supporting user experience of shared automated mobility on-demand through novel virtual infrastructure: Making the case for virtual stops
Fabian Hub
_https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1071581923000526?dgcid=rss_sd_all_

This paper focuses on the design of a vStop HMI for mobile devices (e.g., smartphones) for SAMOD use cases involving shared automated vehicles (SAVs) with ODRP operation strategies. When using SAMOD, users may find themselves in different circumstances and locations when boarding the vehicle, which may complicate the process of accessing the ride, especially in the case of occasional travel behavior. The clear and comprehensible communication of the pick-up location to the user is of great importance. In contrast to conventional bus stops, vStops can be described as pop-up events in public space. They are not marked by physical objects (e.g. signs) to draw the user's attention. In conventional ride-sharing scenarios, uncertainties between riders and drivers in pick-up situations are well-known and can be described as physical meeting problem (Hansen et al., 2010). We assume that, in the case of SAV deployment, this meeting problem could intensify and lead to irritations for users who are trying to find their booked SAV on time. Users need explicit communication of the vStop locations to overcome this physical meeting problem. Accordingly, the need for an HMI to support the user along the user journey derives.

	- Debt trap overstated

items.full_text:
# Slide Notes

Slide 1 Target: Management: Long Tail Dev Patterns and UX
- Long tail effects on development patterns given Apple Vision Pro 
- Required skillsets for post Apple Vision Pro apple development
- From UX Perspective

Slide 2 Target: James: Android Native and Unity 
- Android vs Unity 
	- Most likely android with GLTF elements
	- but possibly unity from the start if 3D is that important 

Slide 1: Target: Management: Long Tail Dev Patterns and UX
Slide 2: Target: James: Unity and Android Native 

**General** 
- Windows, Volumes, and Spaces (Immersive Full Spaces)
	- When a space is activated, it hides other apps 
	- Immersive Space can be full, progressive (partial), and mixed (reality)
	- Need Full Spaces access for app to use world geometry
- Anchors remain persistently for different physical locations
	- World persistence is a system service 
	- Plane Anchor Detection, and are classified (door, windows, etc)
	- Polygonal Mesh Anchors, and are classified (tv, cabinet, seat,  etc)
- 100 meters positional accuracy, but if iphone is nearby, you get iPhone level location tracking 
- "Ornaments" toolbar outside app window for usability 

**Privacy**

- For privacy reasons, dev only get access to which element is being looked and interacted with, rather than where eyes are at all time

**Native**

- Rendering 
	- Shared space shares rendering with other apps 
	- When using Metal directly, use can bypass render server and send directly to compositor 
- Apps
	- Typology of Apps that run as "Windows, Volumes, or Immersive Full Spaces"
- Anchors / Location
	- World persistence is a system service - Anchors Remain persistent in different locations 
	- Having an iPhone nearby increases location accuracy, otherwise 100m
- Plane Anchor Detection, and are classified (door, windows, etc)
- Polygonal Mesh Anchors, and are classified (tv, cabinet, seat,  etc)
- Good spatialized audio, along with visual aids, adds a lot to floating VR interaction "missing haptics"

**SharePlay **
- Group Immersive Spaces (Share Context w/ Personas)

- Can share any window ("like MacOS")
- Spatial Persona Templates (Seating Arrangements)
	- Surround (Tabletop)
	- Conversation (Background)
	- Etc
- Shared Context Window can have individual personal windows into shared context app 

**Safari**

- Utilizes accessibility ARIA metadata for eye selection 
- Require some finessing of CSS tag organization for perfect selection bounds
- Uses embeds of usdz 3d models into html
- Suggesting supportive of WebXR / WebGL stacks

**Design Guidelines **

- Recommend watching video
	- https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2023/10073

- Utilize depth appropriately 
	- keep "main" depth static
	-  when window pops up, keep in same plane but move main window backwards
- Avoid design that draws eyes to edges
	- Round shapes 
	- Avoid Thick outlines 

**Unity **

- Shaders (Shader Graph)
- Materials, sprites, meshes, all auto translated to RealityKit 
- Physically based shader convert directly 
- Occlusion, Unlit Shaders 
- Custom materials made in shader graph are converted to MaterialX
- Play to device (decreases dev time)
- Volume Camera 
- Xcode integration, build to device or simulator in Xcode (like iOS dev)
- URP support foveated rendering 
- "Hand written shaders are not supported, but can be sent to a render texture -> "shader graph" -> RealityKit
- "Volume Camera" takes a region and adds it to Shared Space
	- May need some back faces for meshes clipped by volume camera
- Support built in Unity "Hands" package
- Suggestions 
	- Start using 2022
	- Use ShaderGraph
	- Adopt URP
	- Start using Input System package

Conclusions ===========
- Ecosystem Synergy 
	- Focus on eye tracking seems like no-brainer for integration on other Apple platforms 
		- Also sig more convenient than other XR input methods (consistently been a bar to XR input usage)
	- iPhone location service 
- Opinionated UX framework 
	- better development for end user, given XR is non-standard

items.full_text:
# Lateen replacement of square rig

**Lateen replacement of square rig**
**
**
It is a widespread misconception that the lateen rig replaced square rig because of better windward performance and greater manoeuvrability. 

A study of the relative effectiveness of the two shows that their performance was actually very similar. These results apply both when working to windward and when sailing downwind. (Furthermore, differences in performance are derived as much from the hull shape as the type of rig.) It is concluded that there was no evolutionary technological development that gave improved sailing performance in the 5th century AD change from the Mediterranean square rig to lateen, and that factors other than windward performance must have dictated this change.[26]

The Mediterranean Square Rig underwent a simplification in the 5th century AD, with reduction in the number of components. Most obviously, in the archaeological context, this included the absence of brails (and the distinctive lead rings through which these ropes were led). This change is suggested to be on cost grounds, both reducing the expense of a new build and of ongoing maintenance. This would have given some degradation of performance of this type of square rig. Lateen was already available as an alternative and, having fewer component parts, could compete on cost but maintained the performance of the original Mediterranean Square Rig. This coincided with innovation in hull construction methods as the edge-to-edge joining of the hull planking with pegged tenons (a "shell first" construction technique) started to be replaced with the early evolutionary phases of "frame first" carvel construction. This is also suggested to be driven by costs. Therefore the change from square rig to lateen at the in the 5th century is considered to be driven by construction and maintenance costs, not by any significant difference in sailing performance.[27]

Asahi Kasei Europe’s survey from 2020 reaffirmed this growing trend, with 56.9% of respondents stating connectivity features as an essential part of their next car purchase. In addition, 72.7% agreed that HMIs should be intuitive, including voice and touch screen control.

items.full_text:
# NVIDIA AI MUSINGS 
Reflection
If AI is really shorthand for computing that uses automated processes to distill data into highly parallelizable algorithms via matrix math, which is what GPUs use, then nvidia is in a good place. Given the potential slowing of moores law, it feels like these kind of parallel processors are going to be very important for a long, long, time. 

HOWEVER, everyone is jumping on the 'AI' train in the LLM sense, and there is an overestimation of it's potential use cases and applications. I don't think it will replace as many jobs as the media is piping up.  The only reason LLMs work is because the internet provided a relatively structured limitless NLP data source, that does not apply to all of the really valuable uses for AI, such as highly specific skill niches and the computer vision approaches nvidia researches. For that you need more 3D visual data, and for that you need more relatively high-marginal cost (compared to internet/software) networked camera hardware in the world, which we do not yet have. The real issue I've seen from the inside is that, even with these new technologies, entrenched companies are not changing their culture/processes fast enough. In a capital-poor environment startups (who would use these new tools to structure their organization and culture with extremely minimal friction) are produced in less quantity. Thus the effective sticky adoption rate is going to be not so high.

# Guilt, Shame, Fear Cultures Theory
**GUILT, SHAME, FEAR CULTURES THEORY **
2018
#society #culture #theory #shame #guilt #fear

KEY TAKEAWAYS: 
-   External shame / emphasis on reputation leads to deceit in attempt to save face
-   Creatives must have a dampened sense of shame
-   Christianity is a Guilt culture, which means greater internal debate over external
-   Chinese Daoist original creation myth is abstract, lame, and or insufficient to empower a nation state 
-   According to research Andre found, sino's are ethnically more predisposed to collectivism, and also have lower mental health issues 
-   Guilt cultures emphasize punishment and forgiveness as ways of restoring the moral order; shame cultures stress self-denial and humility as ways of restoring the social order. (Hiebert 1985, 213)
-   More proof for my confirmation bias pet theory that British people are unique because they've been conquered so many times that they feel anxiety over being "civilized" ala more emphasis on socially constructed behavior 
-   Social Media may have emphasized a shame culture via the constant interaction between people, as a result of the breakdown of moral objectivism within enclosed communities

-   the the resulting need for group / community identity validation / affirmation over rival communities 

———————————————————————————————

\-3 categories of culture-

guilt culture, shame culture, fear culture

  

\-guilt culture is associated with christianity, judaism

  

\-shame culture exist in japan, china, and is still leftover in anglo-saxon culture from before their conversion to christianity

  

\-fear culture is more animist and tribal societies

—————————————————————

Guilt cultures emphasize punishment and forgiveness as ways of restoring the moral order; shame cultures stress self-denial and humility as ways of restoring the social order. (Hiebert 1985, 213)

  

a modern interpretation would be that social media has created a modern shame culture

  

as a result of the breakdown of moral objectivism within communities

  

aka post modern concepts of moral relativism

  

and the the resulting need for group / community identity validation

  

"In traditional shame cultures the opposite of shame was honor or “face” — being known as a dignified and upstanding citizen. In the new shame culture, the opposite of shame is celebrity — to be attention-grabbing and aggressively unique on some media platform."

  

would make sense why the brits are so pc

and reflects the theory ive had that they are the most anxious about their identity

cultural anxiety of whether or not they are "civilized" after the shame of being conquered by germanic and nordic vikings, france and the romans

—————————————

"In shame cultures what matters is what other people think of you: the embarrassment, the ignominy, the loss of face. Whereas in guilt cultures it’s what the inner voice of conscience tells you. In shame cultures we’re actors playing our part on the public stage. In guilt cultures we’re engaged in inner conversation with the better angels of our nature."

  

guilt culture seems superior, if the theory that guilt cultures emerge in diverse cultures with well defined non homogenous groups

  

and on top of that ones sense of honor / shame being derived from society means when an external group of superior power comes along, you look like a fool

  

and and furthermore it seems more human, if maybe less civilized, to punish and forgive rather than be in self denial and humility, and try to reject your humanity

  

  

the meme that chinese are the farthest evolved people from apes is strong feeling within me

not that it is good

  

  

but they being hypothetical androgynous collectivist human robots with less individual guilt an mostly communal social shame fearing may be the what propels them past us into the future

  

they dont have a definably main culture myth

  

  

in the way most cultures do

  

  

There was somethi

items.full_text:
# Searle - Brain in Jar
**BRAIN IN JAR SEARLE** 

A brain that is replicating the neural activity of the brain is not necessarily conscious, but could be, dependent on the level of sensory inputs. Derived from Searle, without semantic meaning derived from sensory experience and human chemical reactions to those sensory experiences, the machine may have a duplicate of the human syntax but not necessarily the semantics of consciousness.

  

Emotion and creativity are valued subjectively as reflections on human experience. Such a brain in a jar can create “works of art” and be connect elements in creative ways, but our one of our subjective evaluations of it may be limited as it does not fully comprehend the experience of human life (depends on the two critical views of art independent of context and art dependent on context). I agree with Functionalism, given that it could sense, be mobile, lived an entire human lifetime in the first person, with all sensory inputs and as a duplicated human neural activity into a materialist context, I do think that it would be ‘sapiently’ conscious, or conscious in the human sense, as at that point it is identical to a human.

# Thought on Plastic
It appears to me that there is a disconnect, a market hole, in packaging. While generally this is the the spectrum between that of plastics, which do not biodegrade in any reasonable amount of time, and cardboard, which can biodegrade in reasonable time given correct conditions. 

I argue that there is a need for a material that can fill the economic niche of things that do not begin to degrade until a certain set of time, like 5 years, at which point the degradation process accelerates rapidly. Rather than a linear or exponential half life, this material would have an extreme

items.full_text:
# Physiocracy
**Physiocracy**
#economics  #history #jefferson #agrarianism

Earliest economic theory, predates classical Adam Smith, derived from the belief that land development via agriculture was where wealth of nations came from 

  

"Whereas the mercantilist school of economics held that value in the products of society was created at the point of sale,[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiocracy#cite_note-:0-3) by the seller exchanging his products for more money than the products had "previously" been worth, the physiocratic school of economics was the first to see [labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manual_labor) as the sole source of value. However, for the physiocrats, only agricultural labor created this value in the products of society.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiocracy#cite_note-:0-3) All "industrial" and non-agricultural labors were "unproductive appendages" to agricultural labor.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiocracy#cite_note-:0-3)"

  

// I wonder if this influenced Thomas Jeffersons Yeoman farm ideology

items.full_text:
# Self Class Intro - Oct 2020
INTRO Oct, 2020      

Hey everybody. I'm Conner Ward, from the Bay Area. Im really into IoT Agriculture/Sustainability, chat interfaces, Tabletop RPG's (like DND), Film, pew pew, mountain biking, New Urbanism, Architecture.  
  
Currently running a backyard microfarm for COVID.  
  
My HCI meta-goal is to remove as many physical screens as possible from our lives and further blend the digital space into physical space. 

  
I think Audio-AR interfaces are going to be "the next big thingTM". Look to the future of AirPods. 

  
My aesthetic meta-goal is to make cyberpunk (Im talking Bladerunner 1982 and Gibson Neuromancer here) manifest IRL. Was disappointed when I visited Japan because it was so clean.

items.full_text:
# Spatial Imaginaries

Spatial Imaginaries
https://spatialhistory.net/guide/spatial-imaginaries.html

*"Spatial imaginaries – such as ‘the West,’ ‘Eurasia,’ and ‘the Global South’ – take the form of textual, visual or performative representations. They matter because they reduce complexity and shape identities. They do so by homogenising space. They evoke an ‘imagined community’ (Benedict Anderson), and form part of processes of inclusion and exclusion – determining who is part of this community, and who is not. Spatial imaginaries evoke a sense of belonging and gain traction in response to political challenges: crises, conflicts, and wars. In public discourse, however, geography is typically presented as factual and apolitical, a timeless backdrop to the unfolding of history. All too often spatial imaginaries are taken for granted, their assumptions and intentions left unquestioned.**209** Against this background, scholars have aimed to explore the shifting meanings, political uses, and transnational circulations of spatial imaginaries, through various scales, and across time and space.**210**"**
*
*
*
*"For example, they dismiss the idea of the ‘Third World’ as an ‘unduly monolithic’ political-economic category of the Cold War. Until the concept became redundant when the ‘Second World,’ i.e. the sphere of Soviet communism, transformed after 1989, ‘it served the ideological needs of both Cold War American partisans and, on the opposite side of the political spectrum, the most vigorous opponents of American neo-imperialism.’**219**"*

items.full_text:
# Berkeley
**Berkeley**

I agree with empiricism in that “knowledge claims are tested by reference to sense experience” because as Berkeley suggests, passions and operations of the mind, or reason, are also slave to the perceptions, as are “ideas formed by memory and imagination,” or created ideas. 

  

So we are left with the sensory perceptions to comprehend reality. A reality completely independent of any kind of perceiver is by our understanding inaccessible and therefore in sense does not exist until perceived. For example the hypothetical parts of the universe moving away faster than the speed of light from us, and thus outside our causal event horizon. Assuming there is no way to prove that reality is not a simulation or dream like The Matrix, then it effectively is not, even if beyond our perception it is, just as a universe we can never reach in our current understanding does also cease to exist.

  

However, I also believe that in certain cases it is pragmatic to judge perceptions of the world in Locke’s frame of understanding that of course there are qualia that exist in relation to the observer but also of primary qualities and or simple ideas that exist independent of the observer, because such variables may be observed at a later time, ie it is safer to assume there are latent variables. However I do not think they can be innate to the object, nor is reasonable to consider the value of variables with which we can never interact and/or perceive. Similarly, on a metaphysical level it may be useful to conceptualize the world in Berkeley's subjective idealism as well, particularly the concept of a infinite mind or God, because it allows finite beings to understand the possibly infinitely large and infinitely small reality. 

  

Lastly, I think it is more arrogant to assume that the world exists as we perceive it, because we don't currently know who else might be perceiving it, and possibly differently. So best to assume there are hidden perceivers outside us, ideas beyond our ideas, and latent variables outside our knowledge.

# BS Ramble Religion and Empire
**BS Ramble Religion and Empire**
November 2020
#empire #religion #creation-myth #tribalism
People don't adopt religions for no reason.

They adopt them because it fits their resource related, climate related, needs and fears. But in times of changing variables, such as climate change, this has its share of problems. 

  

From what I have seen - if we live in harsh climates with little resources we look to the individual, to new ideas.

  

If we live in mild climates with many resources we look to the collective, or old ideas. (Renaissance, 1300-1600, coincidently middled between the medieval warm period and European little ice age)

  

\[Note. It seems the long empires are ones that spread along climate similar zones, and be able to fight off those with limited resources from climate north and climate south, that try to steal their resources, as well as the installment of common creation myth, a sort of cultural imperative and justification, to those in the empire. Empire consolidations and the culmination of long wars seem to oddly correlate with max derivative of climate models (most absolute slope between min and max) (ww2/European union, first rise of Rome, fall of Rome, the crusades, Hundred Years' War) I suppose when people have enough resources and are confident being chancy)\]

  

The greatest empires, and the greatest individuals, are those that have the elasticity to do both: individual and collective, past and future. 

  

We must look inside ourselves on par with where we look without. 

  

Jews, look inward to their small community, to a messiah that exists of them, as they do not claim a real homeland. Large connected families are an emergent property of resource poor merchant tribe cultures (post Rome Italian states). They master themselves, each other, and external society values them due fully if enviously (Genoese mercenary crossbowmen). They have been ironically looked down upon due to their apparent disregard responsibility of loyalty to the land where they are living

. 

  

The Christians and muslims creation myth is to look to external messiahs from a past and distant lands. Harsher climates, or more likely to hit by changes in climate (father from temperate bands) reduce resources and they fight amongst themselves till some are fed up, take their family or themselves, and move to another climate zone, where they must interact and feel the need to breed with new people (Neanderthals, Modern Swedes). 

Significant interbreeding reduces the value of the family unit. Their creation myth is we came here from a far away land and took what it had, and had sex with the locals. "Whites" fortunately had many period of distant war with very different cultures wherein "white" power centers were not destroyed by winning or losing the war, (Carthage, ww2, the crusades, colonialism, roman war with Greeks, roman Egypt, Cold War, Vietnam War) each of which empowered and fueled technological and cultural innovation of "white" society. 

  

The Sinos, initially a more tribalistic warring society, have in their creation myth in family / tribe, and thus the past, as their tribe, starting during the first consolidation (Confucianism at end of first Chinese warring states period, pre BC, Tokugawaism after the similar but distant Japanese sengoku jidai), rapidly changed towards looking inward, finalizing with the reconsolidation of China in the Song Dynasty and the collapse Rome and of east west trade. Coincidently (or not) Buddhism, inward looking, expands in this time period. Song China itself, now becoming a real entity, must nationalize to maintain system of such human size, cements the conflation of core family values with values of the country as one hypothetical ethnostate, or The \_\_\_nese. 

  

(Many historians have attributed the fall of Rome to climate change forcing northern tribes to descend.)

  

We have both sides of the dialectic. Where is the synthesis?

  

What has

items.full_text:
# 2045

2021-08-11

Its 2045. People wear some sort of bone/air conducting open ear headphone daily, slightly smarter voice assistant, daily scheduling, slightly better object and location recommendations, that you truly feel like you picked yourself (maybe you did, maybe it was the algo you never can tell). These cheap ubiquitous style of headphones include 3D scanners and head trackers, mapping the world and editing together curated moments from your life. The internet is no longer seen as a collection of html pages, but a backbone for silos / walled gardens. Congress has enacted more technology standardization bills but they can’t keep pace. There still is no unified messaging or voice chat protocols. Lots of smart objects, and the price of integrating sensors and some form of tracking into non electrical and wirelessly charged objects has plummeted. Shoes, bottles, mugs, beds, cars, toilets, laundry bottles, delivery boxes. A new set of large tech companies has emerged among the stalwarts based on a combination of smart objects, decentralized data storage networks related to crypto, information classification and categorization, and 3D mapping. Almost all objects have 3D representations, many are made on the fly. Kids learn 3D modeling and programming in elementary school. Like photoshop and iMovie enabled our generation, in this age 3D viral content (“memes”) are abundant. Having a “drone delivery box” (of varying sizes from mailbox to shipping container) is common sight on curbs. Sweatshops have taken off in Africa, India and China solidify as the worlds manufacturing centers after the completion of the Chinese Belt and Road. Chinese have initiated at least one minor counterinsurgency in Africa and or Micronesia. The “Maker” zeitgeist has faded, and most are starting to see the health effects of being exposed to chemicals during their youth. Things are manufactured “locally” in the same way Amazon warehouses exist on the urban periphery. The price of shipping has remained static given global regulations against oil burning cargo ships and the natural tendency to decrease over time. The northwest passage is open for most of the year and Chinese shipping flows to the US and Europe. The United States is trying to get its shit together and has a few offshoring developments in Africa, South America.

Drugs have been slowly moved towards legalization and regulation 

I watched this great video essay about how films are clearly made by filmmakers. Basically it argued that a lot of plots in movies made by industrial Hollywood reflect the emotions and power structures dealt with during the creation of a movie. In this same way, I feel like voice assistants are pushed by the tech illiterate who only are used to spoken natural language, and the nerds who wear glasses and wish deeply for everyone else to think wearing glasses was cool or at least normal. 

Realistically nobody wants things on their face. Realistically the speed of speech is significantly lower than the speed of typing, and the information density of natural language I think has room for significant compression. 

Acronyms were a response to the constraints of texting, I think they will be mostly replaced in popularity with emojis, gifs, (whatever comes after that with ubiquitous 3D models) and specific slang words like “thot” or “selfie” and word compressions like “deets”

items.full_text:
# Eric Weinstein
**ERIC WEINSTEIN REFLECTIONS**
November 16 2020
#luke-smith #nassim-taleb #eric-weinstein #aesthetics #morals
Running a cult with The Portal 
 
not a bad thing 

COVID is the manifestation of everything the future was going to be 

Silicon Valley tefhnonutopianism, world trade, the death of physical store, the end of sexual abuse because physicality ceases, the collapse of the universities when they admit they can provide the same education at price online, 

  

Common idea: COVID speeds future

  

It also reveals the boomer system was not constructed to be resilient or robust 

Luke Smith / Nassim Taleb 

  

Boomers were products of luck and used institutional manipulation to elongate the world they were accustomed to, thought doing a paper route was the manifestation of their bootstrapping, rather it was the time in place that they were in that determined their outcome, and institutions which perpetuated unsustainable conditions via negative externality debt 

  

Seen in climate change and universities

  

In Eric’s opinion Superposition of ideas presents itself from “a bad question”: ala a question that has no real answer like “are you in favor of the drug war yes or no” “a baby is alive from fertilization vs baby is alive from birth”

Whenever superposition of ideas is present you have a bad question 

This is sort of similar to my idea of argumentative superposition and derivation of cultural knowledge from evolving scientific theory and mass understanding, penetration of science into the zeitgeist, in this case it is the idea that things can be both true simultaneously, Eric adds that this is dependent on asking “bad” questions that have “no solutions on the multiple choice / set of all reasonable answers”

  

Extremist movements are idealistic, based on the concept of aesthetic truth, that is the emergence of truth from something that appears to be true aesthetically 

  

One needs not look farther than far left Soviet sino communists or or far right nazi Germany to see this obsession with aesthetic

  

This is not to say aesthetic truth (that which is beautiful is righteous) is invalid, but rather that it is overvalued by far leaning idealist movements 

  

Far left current identity politics is a great example of this obsession of aesthetics, in the sense that a outward aesthetic quality of gender or race signifies directly the inner workings of the system, rather than actually confronting and analyzing the inner system (possibly due to high complexity)

  

Taste in weinsteins words, or in the common parlance agreed upon frameworks of value, when disputed lead to violence in the semantic sense in Eric’s opinion 

  

common idea: the cause of our current political discourse is an inability to agree on base reality

  

I agree with Eric in that diversity is not necessarily a strength insofar as my pet theory that democracy can only function in homogenous society due to the fact that democracy is predicated on non violent concession, which in Eric’s framework is agreement on base reality 

  

My personal impression is that we must dispense with moral idealism in absolute objective forms and rather accept openly, or ABSOLUTELY ALL UNDERSTAND (highly unlikely) that there is no objective moral framework and that our rationale follows our emotion, in that fighting for moralistic ideals such as “justice” are really masks for our true intentions and or can be manipulated by others, eric mentions this point also in that he believes every great idealistic age can be searched potentially for nefarious elite actions to appropriate this idealism for inequal gains by the top. 

  

Can we dispense with the appeals to emotion? (hard if not impossible)

Solution -> Openly reiterate that our views are opinions 

  

Social media has devalued the opinion market 

Revalue opinions and feelings 

  

Skepticism of markets in long term

items.full_text:
# Realist Economics vs Liberal Economics 
Mearsheimer, Lex Fridman, Shaun

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XXmwyyKcBLk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r4wLXNydzeY

- Realists believe that external structures to states create systems of incentives that lead to great power conflict, specifically over security, IE nations have spheres of influence that they try to keep for security 
	- Mearsheimer also believes that his offensive realism includes actions which in spite of prosperity are undertaken for 'security' // my reading is that 'security' is a term that can be highly semantically cooked to mean anything. He gives the example of ww1, however imo this is a poor example because ww1 in my view was sparked not by actual security concerns but by idealogical commitments to alliances
- // I feel the Zeihan / Diamond naive "map logic" thesis builds off of this but is ultimately suspect 
- Islam is also a good counter example, as it can not be viewed entirely by means of realist policy, as it is a non-rational ideology 
- Mearsheimer outlines liberalism as democracies don't fight each other - Fukuyama -> Mearsheimer argues this is because they can understand each other motives, and that prosperity stops conflict. Mearsheimer believes that survival trumps prosperity, and invokes pre-ww1 prosperity

- To Mearsheimer, Ukraine invasion by Russia was about survival of Russian state, given its potential entry into EU, liberal regime, and NATO // I am partial to this narrative 
	- Mearsheimer argues that Russian invasion size being small (190000) and early negotiation talks were representative of Putin not wanting to annex all of Ukraine, but rather kneecap NATO expansion, as well as Merkel not wanting to support Ukraine because she knew it would lead to war 

- // The EU works only after the creation of a "white European" identity 
- Shaun believes that 'balance of power' from Metternich post Napoleon and Bismarck both failed as they led to revolution, imperial power competition in Africa, and German authoritarianism, respectively. 
- // I heard on BBC talking about Ukrainian 'draft dodgers' and yet pretending to be neutral 

**Conclusion**

- // imo it all comes to ideology, which is influence by external context / structures and institutions, identity, but comes down to what people believe and the people they support to support those beliefs. To what extent which is the largest contributing factor to ideology, I would argue it is internal institutions but that's chicken egg reflexive (there is no true 'origin')

items.full_text:
# Who owns DNS 
SEP 2021
The U.S. Department of Commerce, created InterNIC in 1993 to maintain a central database of registered domain names and their IP addresses in the U.S.
Network Solutions who is a member of InterNIC was initially chosen to administer domain names and IP addresses database. Which is copied to Top Level Domain (TLD) servers around the world
Previously, Network Solutions was the only company authorised to provided domain names. To avoid monopoly, the U.S. government decided to allow other companies to sell domain names (known as registrars). These registrars other than selling Domain names also maintain DNS servers, Still central database is maintained by Network Solutions in the U.S.
There are 13 logical root name servers specified and to provide redundancy in case of one of the root servers fails. Each use a routing technique called anycast addressing to operate from multiple geographical locations .
ICANN manages the DNS Root Servers. Any changes to the root zone file requested by ICANN must be approved by the United States Department of Commerce.

// is this why google owned google domains?
-> google probably sold google domains because they could tell how many subscribers were effectively considering square space websites based on their user data, the level of downtime, etc, but could not figure out how to make money towards google's core products since most people do not maintain domain names without also maintaining a website via a builder. Google I guess did not want to get into the website builder business, might be lower margin.

# 20th Century Corporatism 
https://www.sjsu.edu/faculty/watkins/corporatism.htm

(Not related to modern corporations)
- Coupled with the anti-market sentiments of the medieval culture there was the notion that the rulers of the state had a vital role in promoting *social justice*. Thus corporatism was formulated as a system that emphasized the postive role of the state in guaranteeing social justice and suppressing the moral and social chaos of the population pursuing their own individual self-interests. 
- The basic idea of corporatism is that the society and economy of a country should be organized into major interest groups (sometimes called *corporations*) and representatives of those interest groups settle any problems through negotiation and joint agreement. **
**
- **ESSAY: The TVA Tennessee Valley Authority was a precursor to failed technocratic nation building in Afghanistan and their failed water projects developed by the United States**
- **Corporatist regime typically promote large governmental projects such as TVA on the basis that they are too large to be funded by private enterprise. **

# Web 3 Notes

**Web 3 Notes**

Vanna white effect / Kuleshov effect (you see what is based on context / what your emotions are)
Web 3.0 is an error of periodization 

Image tracking on a public blockchain -> is this compatible with human psychology?

Open Source + Blockchain + Decentralization as a result of open source ?

"People don't want to run their own servers" and yet Wordpress exists. 

"Infrastructure tends towards centralization"? I dunno
Protocols appear to tend towards centralization so far in tech, all the way back to Microsoft. Tech appears to be a winner takes all game. 

"Protocols move slower than a platform" yes. Therefore we need more centralization when it comes to the protocol (Holy Roman Empire approach) 

"Distribute trust not infrastructure" yep.

Moxie also hates technology. (Yep!) Also likes the idea of decreasing labor. 

Heres the thing. Having people host their own instances also involves making sure they update. I think a service which forces updates is one that can iterate faster and nullify the protocol inflexbility. 

"Like any federated protocol, extensions don’t mean much unless everyone applies them, and that’s an almost impossible task in a truly federated landscape." No not really. Its a matter of forcing adoption via market forces, or directly. Apple does this with hardware. 

I agree, that reducing switching costs for consumers is the moral goal. 
Open source + centralized > decentralized ?

// its pretty easy for there to a conflict of interest with moxie.

# Seals Jeans
https://www.heddels.com/2020/12/men-blue-jeans-seals-vietnam-wore-levis/#:~:text=In%20Vietnam%2C%20some%20SEALs%20preferred,donned%20Levi's%20jeans%20in%20combat

In Vietnam, some SEALs preferred American-made Levi’s 501 and 505 denim jeans instead of standard issue dungarees. Specifically during late 1970 and early 1971, SEALs donned Levi’s jeans in combat. Denim could better withstand the rigors of the jungle climate, providing improved protection from leeches, mosquitos and other bugs, especially when combined with a layer of pantyhose underneath.

The following are anecdotes and insights from former Vietnam SEALs:
“Durable, drained faster, didn’t snag, quieter, most ops were at night so wearing cami (camouflage) pants wasn’t necessary.” -Anonymous member of X-Ray platoon 1970/71.
“One reason was the legs were tighter and didn’t rub and make noise when you walked, especially when wet.” -Anonymous member of Mike platoon 1971.

“Levi’s were tighter, tougher, and were easy to take care of. Wash ‘em in the shower after your op.” -Anonymous member of Zulu platoon 1970/71.

items.full_text:
# Arizona Fabs

Arizona Fabs
Qoura
Arizona has pretty much everything a semiconductor fab needs: modern infrastructure, predictable weather, relatively loose environmental controls especially for volatile organic compounds, VOC, and a well trained work force with relatively low cost of living (1/3 the cost for housing as compared to California).
But there is one key reason and that is sodium chloride… salt, or the lack of it. Arizona is far away from the ocean and from any chance of an event that brings salt air anywhere near the fab. Salt is bad for a silicon fab even in minute quantities. The weather is good in the sense that there is a fairly steady external ambient. Yes, the temperature in Arizona changes by 30 degrees from day to night (as compared to 5 degrees in silicon valley) and it does get very hot but the average temperature stays in a manageable range throughout the year and there are very few freezes which don’t last long.
As for humidity, the humidity in a cleanroom is controlled to about 35%. This is the ideal humidity for silicon fabrication especially for photoresist and reduces the incidence of static charge buildup and discharge. *Low humidity* is actually a problem in the cleanroom. A cleanroom will shut down with humidity below 25% to prevent damage from static discharge. If low humidity is a steady condition *external* to the fab, like in Arizona, then the fab has systems in place to control it. In fact, the enemy of fabs are large changes in external humidity. Santa Ana winds are horrible for fabs on the Pacific coast of California. Humidity goes from 60% to 10% overnight. No environmental system can handle that gracefully. There are no large Silicon fabs there because of the salt but there are plenty of smaller fabs that process materials not as sensitive to salt. Sub freezing weather is also bad for fabs in most of the United States (cold air has very little moisture). Again, a large change in external humidity from day to night that goes along with the temperature change really messes up the fab’s environmental controls. All of this can be engineered but it costs money: bigger air handling systems, bigger humidifiers, more energy.
Arizona weather is reasonably stable especially in well insulated dwellings. Internal conditions can be controlled with enough energy. There is plenty of solar energy available if the fab wants to go that route. Infrastructure is good. A fab needs sophisticated supplies from all over the US. A fab can’t afford weather disruptions to deliveries, power and water. I doubt that a shipment of chemicals to Arizona has ever been interrupted by weather. I think the water supply is fairly steady and reliable.
As I said at the beginning, Arizona has pretty much everything a semiconductor fab needs: modern infrastructure, predictable weather, relatively loose environmental controls, a well trained work force with relatively low cost of living and… no salt in the air!

items.full_text:
# San Francisco, Exodus of Agile

San Francisco, Exodus of Agile 
Mar 24 2024
Its clear to me what will happen. The synergy between technological innovation and subsequent organizational innovation (Agile) still have really yet to entered mainstream corporate American industry. This is whats happening. Defense tech, friend-shoring, taking the learning from bay philosophy and transmitting them across the world (no I do not mean the leftism, I mean the software equivalent of Ford's production line. Im 100% certain this will be taught in kids books the same way we are today taught about Ford's line.). This is likely similar to the kinds of process / organizational innovation that happened in the Detroit factories. Software process innovation seems to have really reached an apex, and now it needs talent export. Especially given tech companies are trying to reduce labor costs (and with AI they may be able to reduce engineering costs), it only makes sense for a large exodus of software engineers redistributing across the United States. I do worry that this decentering will slow innovation in software development, but the upside is it will generate an equal amount of innovation in the manufacturing space.

# City of London - City State
**City of London, City States**
#city-state #city-of-london #hong-kong #imperialism #economics #vietnam-war #political-economy 
City of London is an interesting case study of a centralized / strong / unitary independent city state within a nation 

  

Could also be extrapolated to special economic zones, like Hong Kong as a Financial center as well 

-   In this view, Hong Kong as an independent entity is an existential threat to the idea of a Chinese state 

  

Economists are useful not when they create theories but when they empirically analyze case studies 

  

Africa has been exporting wealth at a dramatic rate using City of London networks

  

Financialization of the united states was in response to deindustrialization -> maintaining an economy without actually needing the employees for the elite to function ->

  

During vietnam war -> money was flowing into vietnam -> worried De Gaul would cash it in for gold 

  

Inflow of hot money (tax evasion money) is tool to keep the value of the dollar strong despite a lack of exports

items.full_text:
# Ontology
**Ontology** 

Discussions of dualism versus monism soon lead to the problem of the one and the many . Is there one reality, or are there many different real things that can not be r educed to a single thing? Pluralism is the position that there are many diff er ent real things. This question of one or many, along with the question about what is really real, constitute two fundamental metaphysical problems.

  

Western thought, derived chiefly from the Greeks, has been largely interested in metaphysical and scientific problems, Indian thought largely interested in r eligious problems, and Chinese thought largely interested in moral problems. It is not too much to say that these different approaches to water characterize the Western, the Indian, and the Chinese systems of thought.
