```
items.full_text:
# Capitalist Realism
CH1
- Zizek : "It is easier to imagine the end of the world than it is to remember capitalism"
- "Tradition counts for nothing when it is no longer contested and modified" // what?
- Capitalism subsumes and consumes all of previous history // so does every other historical theory?
- 'Capitalism Realism presents itself as a shield against belief itself'
- Fukuyama's thesis although derided has been absorbed into the cultural unconscious 
- Fredric Jameson: "failure of the future … postmodern culture … dominated by pastiche and revivalism"
    - // in some ways I wonder if a 'failure of the future' is a sort of reaffirmation of the past, even though the "future" was constituted inside the past 
- Thatcher: "There is no other alternative"
- // seems to assume that culture wasn't ALWAYS a function of rehashing old styles in new ways
- // also assumes that there is something wrong with independent and alternative cultures co-inhabiting older forms of resistance 
- "The affinity between hip hop and gangster movies such as Scarface, Godfather, Reservoir Dogs, Goodfellas, and Pulp Fiction arise from their common claim to have stripped the world of the sentimental illusions and seen it for what is really is" a Hobbesian war of all against all, a system of perpetual exploitation and generalized criminality"
    - 'Neo-noir  worldview'
- Davis: "the role of of LA Noire may have been to endorse the emergence of 'homo reaganus'"
- detournement -> using elements of mainstream media to critique it IE They Live 'Obey' signs
- Radiant City / Ville Radieuse -> was an unrealized urban design project designed by the French-Swiss architect Le Corbusier in 1930. It constitutes one of the most influential and controversial urban design doctrines of European modernism.
- Uk Miners Strike 1984 -> Thatcher privatizes UK energy and Coal is replaced by natural gas // -> results in current UK energy prices being very high
CH2
- Films like Wall-E's obese people do anticapitalism for us 
- Ideology does not mask reality, it is a fantasy which ends up structuring reality itself 
- // Live Aid 1985 is exactly capitalist ideology, that we can enjoy ourselves and end hunger, without any political friction or 'systematic organization'
    - "That western consumerism, far from being intrinsically implicated in the systemic global inequalities, could solve the problem itself"
- Bono's Project Red tries to be hip hop rather than hippie, and dispenses with the 
- lurid -> uneasily vivid in color, unpleasant, harsh, shocking
- venal -> susceptible to bribery 
CH3
- "Over the past thirty years, capitalism realism has ascceuufl installed a 'business ontology' in which it is 'simply obvious' that everything in society, including healthcare and education, should be run as a business. // Privatization of the CA grid 
    - "Emancipatory politics must always destroy the appearance of a 'natural order'… turn that which is presented as necessary and inevitable to be a mere contingency, and make what what previously seen as impossible seem attainable."
- When ideology presents itself as empirical fact is when we should be most suspicious 
- Wall-E is the capitalist fantasy of capitalism functioning without labor 
- Neoliberals 'excoriated top down bureaucracy which supposedly led to institutional sclerosis and inefficient in command economies. With the triumph of neoliberalism, bureaucracy was supposed to have been made obsolete, a relic of unlamented Stalinist past"
- // during largesse of Roman Empire, many people were elevated into the lower middle class with jobs in the bureaucracy managing the empire. I have also observed this presently, and strangely the amount of bureaucracy within large public education institutions

items.full_text:
# Algorithms to Live By 
Ch1 Stopping
- **Look Then Leap / 37% Rule** -> assuming ‘hiring problem ‘(where candidates must be accepted or dismissed) ‘**look**’ at first 37% of applicants then be prepared to ‘**leap**’ and choose the next best applicant, since your chances of finding the best candidate start to decrease after the first 37% of sampling 
	- Love Modification (With ability to fallback to previous candidates, and possibility of rejection by candidate) - Start making proposals after first 25%, also 25% odds of success 
- ? Sampling without replacement, ‘no information game’ (relative to each other) -> Start leaping at 37% ? 
- ? Sampling with replacement, ‘no information game’ (relative to each other) -> Start leaping / falling back to previous candidates at 63% ?
- Sampling, with information game (ex. Standardized test scores) -> top 97th percentile  
	- Threshold Rule -> 58% chance of success, given standardized test scores Noting how many applicants are remaining, as options dwindle, percentile of results drops off like Type 1 survivorship curve, or in other words, a concave log curve

![Algorithms to Live By](images/Algorithms%20to%20Live%20By.png)

	- 1. Concave Log 2. Linear 3. Convex Log, or Exponential Decay or convex log 
	- *“Gold digging is more likely to succeed than a quest for love.”*

- Parking 
	- // Differs from peoples usage, people usually drive to location and then outward, not towards a location linearly
	- Based on projected occupancy rates, distance to park from destination is similarly distributed, where an 85% occupancy rate means parking “5 spots” from destination 
	- As a process, like unemployment in the economy, *“Empty spots on highly desirable blocks means things are working properly”* rather than simply maximizing utilization of a resource ie parking spots.

- *“The flow of time turns all decision making into [an] optimal stopping [problem].”*
	- Most people in Rapport and Seale study found people stopped early resulting in 31% success rate, because cost of time was endogenously(internally)/implicitly imbued into their search, given life experiences are mediated by time 
- CH2 Explore Exploit
	* Multi Armed Bandit Problem (Slot machine one armed bandit)
	* Human action value function curve -> define a curve of the distributions of rewards from todays actions will server tomorrows you’s
	* Play slot machines with highest odds (so not penny slots)
	* Win Stay Lose Shift - stay until lose, then switch // naive
	* Gittins Index
	* // Jeff Bezos shares my regret minimization framework
	* Upper Confidence Bound Algortithms 
	* “You don’t get good payoffs during the exploration phase”
	* When young people were told they’d move far away, they were more likely to pick spending time with family over friends or new people with shared interests
	* When old people were told they’d get 20 extra years of lifespan, their preferences changes to be similar to young peoples

The Digital Collection System Network (DCSNet) is the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)'s point-and-click surveillance system that can perform instant wiretaps on almost any telecommunications device in the US.[1]

It allows access to cellphone, landline, SMS communications anywhere in the US from a point-and-click interface. It runs on a fiber-optic backbone that's separate from the internet.[2]

![Surveillance-1](images/Surveillance-1.png)

Health and biological information TIA collected included drug prescriptions,[8] medical records,[39] fingerprints, gait, face and iris data,[12] and DNA.[40]

It is powered by a remote radar and responds by modulating the VGA red signal (which is also sent out most DVI ports) into the RF signal it re-radiates; this method of transmission is codenamed VAGRANT.

items.full_text:
# GREENLAND: FAILURE OF THE NORSE AND DYSTOPIA
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Greenland#Norse_failure

Sep 10 2021

To investigate the possibility of climatic cooling, scientists drilled into the Greenland ice cap to obtain core samples, which suggested that the Medieval Warm Period had caused a relatively milder climate in Greenland, lasting from roughly 800 to 1200. However, from 1300 or so the climate began to cool. By 1420, the "Little Ice Age" had reached intense levels in Greenland.[26] Excavations of middens from the Norse farms in both Greenland and Iceland show the shift from the bones of cows and pigs to those of sheep and goats. As the winters lengthened, and the springs and summers shortened, there must have been less and less time for Greenlanders to grow hay.

Bone samples from Greenland Norse cemeteries confirm that the typical Greenlander diet had increased by this time from 20% sea animals to 80%.[28]

The Norse never learned the Inuit techniques of kayak navigation or ring seal hunting.
## 

The last reported ship to reach Greenland was a private ship that was "blown off course", reaching Greenland in 1406, and departing in 1410 with the last news of Greenland: the burning at the stake of a condemned male witch, the insanity and death of the woman this witch was accused of attempting to seduce through witchcraft, and the marriage of the ship's captain, Thorsteinn Ólafsson, to another Icelander, Sigríður Björnsdóttir.[34]

![GREENLAND- FAILURE OF THE NORSE AND DYSTOPIA](images/GREENLAND-%20FAILURE%20OF%20THE%20NORSE%20AND%20DYSTOPIA.png)

A plantation of exotic arctic trees was created in 1954 near Narsarsuaq.[58]
The attempt to introduce European-style urban housing suffered from such inattention to local detail that Inuit could not fit through the doors in their winter clothing and fire escapes were constantly blocked by fishing gear too bulky to fit into the cramped apartments.[59] T
During the first years there were minor problems with coagulated blood clogging up the drainage, stemming from the fishermen using the only available reasonable place to carve up their catch: the bathtubs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vinland
```

items.full_text:
# Qoura on Meditation
**MEDITATION - QOURA**
```
Others have provided some good comments. I would add that real happiness exists in a lasting way only at the deepest level of your mind, which is naturally and unconditionally happy. Material goals can be only temporarily satisfying. That's why people keep wanting more and more; they hope they will be satisfied. "If I get another car, maybe I'll be happy." So they keep getting more cars and more cars. Or more electric guitars; some people have literally several dozen guitars. Or more real estate. Or a different wife or girlfriend. All these things can be pleasing in the short run, but then the hunger for happiness is active again, and people look for things that will satisfy it.

Perhaps the preceding comments will cause you to develop different or bigger material goals. If so, you will always be wanting more. Even billionaires want more billions.

Perhaps your current feeling of frustration and disappointment results from recognition of this truth. On some level, you know material gains are only temporarily satisfying, and you want to know what else can be done.

For me, the answer is contacting the quietest level of my mind every morning and every evening. This quiet mental state leads to a quiet physical state of the body, and I get rest that is deeper than I get after hours of sleep. It's enjoyable, but the best part is that afterwards, some of the happiness that exists at the quietest level of the mind stays with me when I am in activity, so I am happier. The deep rest causes stress to be released from the body and the nervous system, so I am healthier. And my thinking is improved, so I am more productive. When I started doing this, I was not focused on long-term goals. I was just trying to have fun in the evenings and on weekends. Expecting to remain in the business world, I knew I needed an MBA, but I just didn't want to do the work. After a while, my thinking and motivation naturally improved, and I decided to earn the MBA. A few years later, I decided I wanted to be a management professor, and I entered and completed a PhD program. Then, I worked as a professor for over 20 years before retiring earlier this year. I doubt that I would have entered graduate school if I had not learned Transcendental Meditation. It remains a daily source of happiness and amazement for me, and I have been doing it for over 40 years. It's easy. It does not involve concentration. It allows the mind to naturally become quiet, something that is not elusive. If you can run, you have the ability to stand still. Similarly, if you can think, you can experience a quiet mind. Only the right technique is needed. TM is a reliable way to have this experience, and people often report their very first meditation with TM was a new and wonderful experience.

Practicing TM, you take happiness with you into activity, and all your activities become more satisfying. I expect that you would finally identify goals that would lead to greater satisfaction for you, and you would enjoy them more because of the happiness you develop in meditation.

If this sounds at all interesting, I suggest you go to the website [Learn about the Transcendental Meditation technique.](http://tm.org/)

  

You may be on the threshold of a phase in your life that is better than you ever thought possible.

Best wishes.
```

items.full_text:
# Reality in Fiction - Violence
REALITY IN FICTION MEDIA - VIOLENCE

No Date

Are we above our interests?

  

It is more dangerous to assume than to question. 

  

The skeptical viewpoint on this topic would be to challenge the assumption that media does not influence us.

  

The underlying question is about the influence our media has on our actions, and if our brains differentiate reality and fiction to the extent that it does not influence our behaviours.

  

The very nature of the mass adoption of narrative media should be enough to explain, as well as the ability for one to interact with a film television show or game. 

  

**The brain does indeed value the real greater than the fictional**

Sixty male subjects were either attacked or treated neutrally by a confederate, after which each saw a videotape of two men fighting. Subjects were informed that fight was either real or fictitious or were given no explanation of it. Subjects who had previously been attacked and had observed the fight under a set to perceive it as real were subsequently more punitive in their treatment of the confederate than subjects in all other conditions. The combination of prior attack and observation of real violence also sustained blood pressure (BP) at near the level produced by the attack, whereas BP of attacked subjects in the other conditions declined during the time the fight was observed. Palmar sweat measures revealed that observation of real violence was more arousing than observation of fictitious fighting. The results are discussed in terms of the effects that the reality of observed violence has on emotional arousal.

  

**However what is determined as “real” is influenced by empathetic connection** 

Serial programs, in particular, create viewer involvement with recurring characters' fictional lives (Zillmann & Bryant, [2002](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15205430902813856?casa_token=T5gVN0XNc-AAAAAA:BWyw3V_yce4Ttb5_bpSPP5VXnobGAb61PL3GszcOiFgUHGAfW4llsvGbDZ7dHutWPlj913kVMTckqw%23)Zillmann , D. , & Bryant , J. (2002 ). Entertainment as media effects . In J. Bryant &D. Zillmann (Eds.), _Media effects: Advances in theory and research (_ , 2nd ed. , pp.437 – 462 ). Hillsdale , NJ :Erlbaum . [\[Google Scholar\]](http://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?hl=en&publication_year=2002&pages=437-462&author=D.+Zillmannauthor=J.+Bryant&title=+Media+effects%253A+Advances+in+theory+and+research+%2528+)). Moreover, the plotlines in fictional narratives may be sufficiently long and complex that viewers are essentially “transported” into the story, thus temporarily losing sight of the fictional nature of the narrative. “Transportation” has been shown to facilitate persuasion in studies of print narratives, mainly because transportation stimulates feelings of empathy for characters in the story (Green & Brock, [2002](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15205430902813856?casa_token=T5gVN0XNc-AAAAAA:BWyw3V_yce4Ttb5_bpSPP5VXnobGAb61PL3GszcOiFgUHGAfW4llsvGbDZ7dHutWPlj913kVMTckqw%23)Green , M. C. , & Brock , T. C. (2002 ). In the mind's eye: Transportation-imagery model of narrative persuasion . In M. C. Green , J. J. Strange , & T. C. Brock(Eds.), _Narrative impact: Social and cognitive foundations_(pp. 315 – 342 ). Mahwah , NJ :Erlbaum . [\[Google Scholar\]](http://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?hl=en&publication_year=2002&pages=315-342&author=M.+C.+Greenauthor=T.+C.+Brock&title=+Narrative+impact%253A+Social+and+cognitive+foundations+)).

  

 Viewers, who watched a program emphasizing flaws in the justice system, demonstrated attitudes that were significantly more pro-defendant/anti-criminal justice system than those who viewed the more positive storyline. It was particularly surprising that attitudes toward the death penalty, which are often seen as deep-seated and immutable, varied by these episodes (Bobo & Johnson, [2004](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15205430902813856?casa_token=T5gVN0XNc-AAAAAA:BWyw3

# Vietnam Notes
      

**Vietnam Notes**

Dennis-Mulgannon\\qoura

  

_Loud and Clear, or Lima Chuck_

  

Another way to respond, also a carryover from code words, was by scaling from 1 to 5 on signal strength and clarity. So the response would be _I hear you five by five_ for a perfect signal, or _I hear you five square_. In many, many cases in fox mike when you are in a hole or very close to being out of range, the response might be _four by two_, meaning that the signal is fairly strong but its intelligibility is very weak.

  

_Jumping Jack_

  

_Wait-out_ meant I was very busy, you are my lowest priority, and I will call you back, so quit bothering me. Occasionally, when someone is stepping on your communications, _Get the F--- off my net, this is a denied frequency!_ Then the ASA (I think that was their initials) would file a complaint which went nowhere, either that or it is still in the processing queue.

  

Psyops

There was a second lieutenant at 3d Mobile, Long Hai, Vietnam. He headed up S-5 duties in the area. During a break following a mortar attack he was out at the bunker wall with a bull horn, with the assistance of an interpreter, attempting to encourage our enemy to surrender. In response, our enemy shipped us a couple more truckloads of 82-mm. The poor _2nd-Lt_ never heard the end of it.

  

  

\[MPC (Military Pay Currency was preferred over Pia (Piastres). I believe that equivalent was $10-MPC = 1000-Pia. The legal exchange rate was roughly 1500-Pia to $10-MPC. But on the black market the fluctuation would be much greater, as it could go as high as 3.5 to 1.

  

Trading MPC for Piastres on the blackmarket was definitely illegal, but would not be treated as high treason. However, Greenbacks (the US Dollar) which traded for up to 3 to one MPC, and 10 to one Pia on the blackmarket could land you in Federal Military Prison.\]

  

 Some used their alcohol and tobacco rations to buy the items at the PX, then sell them on the black market. American booze and cigarette (particularly menthol flavored) sold for a very high price on the black market. Every street vendor had a couple of American brand cigarette packs for sale, which was worth anywhere from 2 to 5 times the Post Exchange price.

  

Vung Tau could be dangerous at night, but not from VC. The slang for gang-bangers or thugs was _Cowboys._ Cowboys would roll drunk Americans for MPC. Sometimes a GI would be killed, just like in Los Angeles, California, or New York City. Another good buddy—callsign Flex—loved to bait Cowboys by pretending to be drunk.

  

A klick or so, maybe two outside the compound was an A-Camp. Every night, tracers would fly out from the night as sparks from a grinding wheel, and while howitzers would _fire for effect!._ launching fifty-fives out over my head as I sat on the bunker wall—a _nubee_—watching the fireworks. As the rounds hit, sparks would fly out _white, then red then out,_ just like a fireworks display at Disneyland. It seemed to be about the same time every night, around 10-ish (22:00).

  

The PRC-46 had the option to connect to an electronic scrambling device. However, this type of scrambling was not practical for use by units in the field, on the move.

  

**_How the enemy could screw with us via radio:_** As mentioned previously, all the enemy needed was the frequency—not the actual radio—for the purpose of screwing with troops.

1.  Jamming was very common, not only by our enemy, but also by friendly troops walking over another’s transmission. Line of sight—FM—communications was _simplex_ meaning that unlike a telephone, two radios within range of each other could not transmit at the same time. Depending upon the strength of the signal, when two or more radios try to talk at the same time, you would hear a loud squeal. So, if the enemy were pretty much in a position that they were bound and determined to defend, if they knew your frequency, all t

# Conspiracy Thinkers
**Conspiracy Thinkers**
#emergent-properties #convergent-evolution #conspiracy #education #evolution #religion #ancient-architects #joe-rogan
**Emergent Properties**
Just had a thought that conspiracy theorists really only do one thing wrong, they attribute the will that they validly perceive as the will of individuals rather than an "invisible hand" type emergent will of multiple forces. The idea of emergent properties is also something tied directly with comprehending the seemingly directed randomness of evolution. An actionable solution then would be to demonstrate at a young age the existence of emergent properties

**As a core element of early education**
Probably one of the famous ones would be demonstrating centrifugal force with a bucket of water and asking the students how they think it works

**As attributing events to individuals**
Id imagine living in a less populated area like a rural zone probably also predisposes you do believing in the will of individuals over the emergent will of the horde, or like a belief in a humanistic deity 

**As attributing intention to convergence or emergence**
// What do you call something that has been emergently designed?
also conspiracy thinkers devalue the concept of convergence (in thinking and evolution) and attribute it to one grand narrative or direct lineage (ancient architects)

you can see this directly in the "one global civilization that built all the megalithic stone sites across the world" meme perpetuated by Joe Rogan and people he brings on

It couldn't possibly be that humans with similar tools and environments converge on methods and reasons for building stone architecture

Comparing it back to evolution, there's so many instances of animals that converged on traits based on having similar niche in food web, even from extremely distantly related animals. With that framework I don't think its that hard to comprehend that many cultures around the world with similar climatic, technological, and population density features converged on the same methods of hauling, forming, and placing stones

# Connerian Manifesto - 2018
**2018 CONNERIAN MANIFESTO**
2018
#manifesto #goals #morals #ethics #reflection 

_NOTE: Any references to science is not to draw truth from science but rather to utilize the relationships as metaphors for understanding the complexity of life; just as the animists believed the universe was spirits, the renaissance believed life was a clockwork, and we now increasingly perceive life as a simulation._ 

  

KEY TAKEAWAYS: (D means difficult integrating) (2020)

-   Protect your inputs - _Do not become a product of a seemingly inescapable environment_
-   “You might not have noticed, but your brain did.”
-   Words are power
-   Everything matters
-   (D) Obstacle as opportunity
-   Creation Myths are powerful, windows to the future
-   True self service many times involves empowering others
-   (D) man must humble himself before he can refuse to be humbled 
-   Collapse reality. Look into the void. Peer into the Box, do not let it stay as potential only.
-   Life as Vectors, only having direction and magnitude. No privileged observer (rather than dimensions with positive and negative)
-   Your face and body is a tapestry of your good and bad health decisions 
-   Assume Nothing - _communicate (receive and send) frequently, with truth probes every so often_
-   Perception is relative - _rewrite your past_
-   Result oriented behavior is the philosophy of business but not the philosophy of man.
-   Other people do not matter until you matter to other people.
-   You must constantly die to be constantly reborn. 
-   Life is promises - If we keep making promises, we may never notice how many are broken
-   Life's progression: Raise a plant, raise a dog, raise a kid, raise your parents
-   Rewrite your past
-   (D) Enjoy the process - _more than the result, because the result will always differ from vision (keep your expectation in check)_
-   _"If ya always got your way all the time, think about how many people wouldn't get theirs."_ (Life as zero sum)
-   Elements of religion, such as sacrifice, positive worship of existence, admittance of guilt
-   You are the product of your actions and environment (which does not mean you are absolved of fault, you are always responsibility for levels of awareness and reaction thusly).
-   Time does not rest - _Indecision and inaction are the only thing that causes regrets_

_PERSONAL REFLECTIONS / ANXIETIES_ 

-   My father/family lacks a tradition of excellence, but excellent in brute force willpower (farm people thoughts)
-   I have unresolved anxiety of becoming a depressed, average, parent 

\-------------------------------------------------------

**Connerian Manifesto: When we realize the world is incomprehensible**

  

My largest underlying fear is that there is a existential deterministic timeline in which we all become depressed parents who give up our dreams and the idealized self for something “greater” that lives beyond us, and that true happiness in society always is about having children and working up the corporate ladder, the dominance hierarchy, to get a stay at home trophy wife, rather than becoming what we ourselves think we want to be. 

  

I for one love children, but am attempting to be conscious of the costs of raising a child and its significance in limiting one’s ability to tread “their own path”. The problem here is not making mistakes. It is is indecision given the never stopping ticking clock of time. If we do not truly want something, with the utmost conversional truth of want to NEED, it does not come into existence. When something is truly wanted, it informs all decisions, all actions, conscious and not. 

  

A mantra that will be repeated here, adapted from talk show host Mike Stoklasa is as follows:

“You might not have noticed, but your brain did.”

  

The clock is ticking.

  

When you hit 45, and aren’t married, we think something must be wrong. We are both free and a

# Heidigger, Kierkagaard, Camus, Kant
Heidigger, Kierkagaard, Camus, Kant 

Heidigger- disagree with "authenticity" dilemma, agree with his hatred of descarte 

**Kierkagaard- agree with balance of infinity and finite and choose the finite, laugh that of course a anxious philopsher would value anxiety as the means to enlightenment** 

-   "Ridding oneself of the self is what people who can not deal with the anxiety do" sounds doubtful and disparaging against things that Kirk doesn't like 
-   Agree with subjective of others dilemma
-   Kierkegaard directly relates to hipsterism 
-   Aesthetic (vulgar and refined aesthete) living is despair (what I see in Ricardo)
-   I agree that the civic duty minded ethicist that derives value from children is at some point a high good, however a high reliance on this is not good (like my dear mother)

  

Camus- agree that socialism is the deification of man

Utopia at the end of time is heaven metaphor 

  

I agree with Kantian post Hume that reality is appeared based on space, time and causality. Very modern thought for early 18000s

I agree with transcedtal objects that we can never know, disagree with shopenhaur

Shopenhaur "will to live" is the biological imperative 

The way I decontextualize will is "objects in motion tend to stay in motion" in relation to shope saying even inanimate objects are representations of will. Or that inamaitne objects means "will" is effectively a blind force of energy, the same way the universe is expanding

  

My idea: compassion via selfishnis 

  

Something that really threw me for a loop was that cards in the game Fiasco were between players, they represented relationships. In Mintzberg and Gosling they also mention that "collaboration" in the west is seen as organization of humans rather than the organization of relationships 

  

IM on spinozas side of metaphorical pantheism

# Plants - Academic Research
Woodchip bioreactors
- can reduce nitrate runoff ( #unverified )

Biochar
- raises ph 
- reduces salt uptake
- reduces oxidative stress in salted soils
- increase microbial biomass
- may store contaminants such as heavy metals
- any other claims are speculative

Microplastics 
- 5240g may be ingested per day in EU
- Microplastics absorb heavy metals from soil
- industrial compost has more microplastics 


Dynamic Accumulators
- Stinging Nettle, Dandelion and Lambsquarter only relevant accumulators of NPK and trace minerals
- Rest are speculative claims

Houseplants
- houseplants do not increase AQI

# Dream - Down by the River side
      

**Dream**
Down by the river side

Bravely bold sir robin style elongated pause singing

In Iowa, me grandpa and father went to the local field, where dad was telling me he and the brothers once dug and entire trench system. One day, the school tractor was coming through the field and got stuck in one of the covered trenches, putting an end to that summer. There was some scrap wood sitting around in the corner, and I was making a miniature version and thinking how could he of accomplished something so large, and how could he have hidden it. My father was working on closing up an old gate that led to the riverside, where people took tea, a path that was long forgotten public space. 

  

Suddenly on the other side of the fence, a large creature, something I had never seen before or since, like a giant bird, an ostrich but with green and yellow head feathers and a white body, neck snapping into action to quickly nibble the insect in the dirt.

  

A man on the other side of the gate, also using the quarantine time to build up his gardens and fences, noticed us, enraged. He also noticed the bird, and explained he had seen these before. It snapped at him and he recoiled, but got it to escape back into the bush. What are you doing he said, I was just about to fix this. My father explained that this gate hadn’t been used in decades, but the other man explained that he had been keeping the area leading up to the gate clear to one day repair the gate. This was a large two door gate, with a trellis above it, and black cast iron hardware, with old growth wood faded but lasting the test of time. To end the bickering, I said to the man that we didn’t know you wanted to use it, and we would stop. He smiled, and agreed. I crawled through the hole in the wall leading back to the river path, got stuck and had to be pushed out, hit some old barbed wire with my face, but other than that, we walked back to grandmothers mid century, no AC, rough rock and palm and cloudy yellow bottle glass, lobby house. 

  

Personally, I don’t know why my father was trying to board up those holes in the fence and gate. In a child’s eyes, those were portals to adventure, long forgotten and forsaken by the adults of the age, doors to lost worlds.

# Amazon S3 Bugs
**Amazon S3 Bugs**
```
In February 2017, Amazon accidentally brought down swaths of the internet when one of its employees, trying to debug the company’s S3 service, entered a command incorrectly. Because hundreds of thousands of companies use S3 to store data, the error took down tons of sites, including Quora, Giphy, and Slack. Ironically, Amazon’s own S3 status indicator relied on S3, which is why it incorrectly reported that the service was working just fine during the outage.
```

```
# Okhlahoma
**OKHLAHOMA** 

Boomer "Unallocated Land" Anti-Indian Movement 
```
The first group was participants in the "Boomer Movement." These participants were white settlers from 1879–1889 who believed the so-called "Unassigned Lands" within the Indian Territory were public property and open to anyone for settlement, not just Indian tribes. Their belief was based on a clause in the Homestead Act of 1862 which said that any settler could claim 160 acres (0.65 km2; 0.25 sq mi) of "public land."\[1\]

President Grover Cleveland opened the Indian Territory to settlement by signing the Indian Appropriations Act of 1889 on March 2, 1889.\[4\] The result was the Land Rush of 1889. In it, rushers could be divided into two groups: the Sooners were settlers who entered the Unassigned Lands just prior to the April 22, 1889 official opening in a race to grab the best land, while the ones who waited until the actual opening date are also sometimes referred to as "Boomers", confusingly.\[5\]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_Acts#Homestead_Act_of_1862

The "yeoman farmer" ideal of Jeffersonian democracy was still a powerful influence in American politics during the 1840–1850s, with many politicians believing a homestead act would help increase the number of "virtuous yeomen". The Free Soil Party of 1848–52, and the new Republican Party after 1854, demanded that the new lands opening up in the west be made available to independent farmers, rather than wealthy planters who would develop it with the use of slaves forcing the yeomen farmers onto marginal lands.\[6\] Southern Democrats had continually fought (and defeated) previous homestead law proposals, as they feared free land would attract European immigrants and poor Southern whites to the west.\[7\]\[8\]\[9\] After the South seceded and their delegates left Congress in 1861, the Republicans and other supporters from the upper South passed a homestead act.\[10\]

The first known novels to be set on a desert island were Hayy ibn Yaqdhan written by Ibn Tufail (1105–1185), followed by Theologus Autodidactus written by Ibn al-Nafis (1213–1288). The protagonists in both (Hayy in Hayy ibn Yaqdhan and Kamil in Theologus Autodidactus) are feral children living in seclusion on a deserted island, until they eventually come in contact with castaways from the outside world who are stranded on the island.... William Shakespeare's 1610–11 play, The Tempest, uses the idea of being stranded on a desert island as a pretext for the action of the play.

```
# Causes of Vietnam War Yahoo Answers
**Causes of Vietnam War**
Presented by Yahoo Answers

```
That is a good question... and the fact that American political and military leaders were increasingly at a loss to give a good answer led to the withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam. 

Let's go back to the 1920s when a young man by the name of Ho Chi Minh started opposing the French occupation of Indochina, which included Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam. This opposition was a low-level insurgency that made little headway until 1940. In 1940, German forces overwhelmed France, occupied Northern France and established the puppet Vichy French government in Southern France. The Japanese, allies to the Germans, had their allies force the Vichy French to allow Japanese troops to occupy Indochina. In 1944/45, with German forces being expelled from France and Vichy French officials in Indochina talking the Allies, Japan took over Indochina and interned the French. 

Now, because the Viet Minh, headed by Ho Chi Minh, were fighting against the Japanese -- as well as the Vichy French -- the United States sent OSS agents, the forerunner of the CIA, into North Vietnam to assist Ho. Ho was impressed by the OSS agents and they were impressed by his organization, which they described, and maybe accurately, as more nationalist than communist in nature. Ho requested that the OSS provide him with a copy of the American Constitution and Declaration of Independence. He then wrote a constitution for an independent Vietnam based -- at least in part -- on those documents. When Japan was defeated in 1945, Ho declared Vietnam independent. Many OSS agents believed and campaigned for the United States to recognize an independent Vietnam. 

It's amazing how much impact global politics in Europe impacted Vietnam in these years. France, though, wanted Indochina back. They threatened to ally themselves with the Soviet Union if their pre-war colonies, including French Indochina, were not returned to them. And so the U.S. abandoned Ho Chi Minh in 1946. In 1954, Viet Minh beat the French at Dein Bein Phu, an isolated post in North Vietnam, and forced the French to leave the country. By then, geo-political events had turned against a now fully Communist Ho Chi Minh. And, under the dictates of the Cold War domino theory, which stated that if one nation in a region fell to Communism, then all nations would eventually fall, the United States became the primary supporter of the new Kingdom of South Vietnam, which quickly became the Republic of South Vietnam. Our aim, then, was to support the South Vietnam government against Communist agression in the context of a global ideological war between the United States and the Soviet Union (rarely did soldiers from the two sides exchange gunshots, although it rarely did happen in Korea, Vietnam and other hotspots). 

So, as OSS agents argued in 1945/46, there were no material United States vital interests in Indochina that would cause the U.S. to automatically reject a government by Ho Chi Minh. It was the political interests the U.S. had in Europe against the Soviet Union that led it to allow France to re-establish its Indochinese colonies. And later it was the U.S. global geo-political interests -- also against the Soviet Union -- that led to U.S. support for South Vietnam. 

But, Vietnam did not provide any rare resouces to American companies. We could get rubber elsewhere. Although Cam Rahn Bay has a deep, natural port, the United States did not need the base for its Asian operations and the Soviet Union never possessed a sufficent blue water navy to take military advantage of the harbor. There was no chance of a mass invasion of the United States from Vietnam, and the United States did not have that many strong allies, other than Thailand, in the area. # Early History of Scifi
```
EARLY HISTORY OF SCIFI
Pre-Modern Science Fiction
```
L'Autre Monde: ou les États et Empires de la Lune (Comical History of the States and Empires of the Moon) (1657) was the first of three satirical novels written by Cyrano de Bergerac, that are considered among the first science fiction stories. Arthur C Clarke credited this book with conceiving of the ramjet,\[3\] and being the first fictional example of a rocket-powered space flight.

He meets the Moon's inhabitants, who have four legs, musical voices, and fantastical weapons that cook game for a meal as it's shot. He also meets the ghost of Socrates and Domingo Gonsales of Francis Godwin's The Man in the Moone. His discussions with Gonsales include how God is useless as a concept, that humans cannot achieve immortality, and that they do not have souls. After these discussions, the narrator returns to Earth.

  

During the European [Middle Ages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Ages), science fictional themes appeared within many [chivalric romance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chivalric_romance) and legends. [Robots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot) and [automata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automaton) featured in romances starting in the twelfth century, with [_Le Pèlerinage de Charlemagne_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_P%C3%A8lerinage_de_Charlemagne) and [_Eneas_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eneas) among the first.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_fiction#cite_note-29)

Automata in these works were often ambivalently associated with [necromancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Necromancy), and frequently guarded entrances or provided warning of intruders.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_fiction#cite_note-31) This association with necromancy often leads to the appearance of automata guarding tombs, as they do in _Eneas_, [_Floris and Blancheflour_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floris_and_Blancheflour), and _Le Roman d’Alexandre_, while in [Lancelot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lancelot) they appear in an underground palace.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_fiction#cite_note-32) 

  

States similar to [suspended animation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suspended_animation) also appear in medieval romances, such as the Histora Destructionis Troiae and the Roman d’Eneas. In the former, king [Priam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priam) has the body of the hero [Hector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hector) entombed in a network of golden tubes that run through his body. Through these tubes ran the semi-legendary fluid [balsam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balsam) which was then reputed to have the power to preserve life. This fluid kept the corpse of Hector preserved as if he was still alive, maintaining him in a [persistent vegetative state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistent_vegetative_state) during which [autonomic processes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system) such as the growth of facial hair continued.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_fiction#cite_note-35)
```
  

Personal concept of "Social Fiction" as a meta category of speculative fiction

# Oil Paleogeologist
**OIL PALEOGEOLOGIST**

A fascinating article from Quartz explains how oil companies are looking back 200 million years to Pangaea, the supercontinent that once made up all land on Earth. Brazil was once next to Nigeria; Washington, D.C., was once next to Western Sahara. And it turns out that if you discover oil somewhere–say, Ghana–there’s a very good chance that you’ll find more of it across the ocean in the spot that once was connected.

  

Paleogeologists (aka “paleomagicians,” in the industry) also have to find more evidence that oil actually exists in a certain location. But starting with the puzzle of Pangaea has already led to several new discoveries: Oil in Brazil led to a new discovery in Angola, oil in Ghana led to a new discovery in French Guiana, and the list goes on.

# Personal Informatics
**Personal Informatics**
In summary, personal informatics has usually unattributed intrapersonal social components. Despite the study’s observation of low social feature use, such as sharing to facebook, the study references the social components of tracking. Some such components are commitment to brand, particularly in Nike users, competing with strangers on the app, tracking compared amongst social groups like family, friends and coworkers, and the actual physical device being worn as a talking point and representing similar held ideals. The study suggests that users only like to compete health data with complete strangers, or close social circles, rather than tertiary facebook acquaintances, or what I would call “your personal facing public”. In our skit, it was between a such small social circle and the social validation of health tracking apps within a small social group as a precursor to adoption of said health tracking app. 

These social drivers are also referenced in the article, which while raising many more questions than it answers, I found contained the fascinating question of “narrative-health” or the anxiety that quantified health may lead to decrease in asking “how do you feel” replaced instead with “what does the data say.” While I think most likely we will find balance of this in the future, I do wonder what kind of doctor-patient relationships will emerge when the data shows clear deviations from how the patient say they feel. Similarly, given the situation in the skit, how would such a data-emotional dissonance affect friend and family relations? 

```
“You say you feel better but your health data says otherwise!”

Kurt Gerstein (the Chief Disinfection Officer) argued that carbon monoxide gassing left a greater mess than Zyklon-B. When the doors of the carbon monoxide chamber opened, “the bodies were thrown out blue, wet with sweat and urine, the legs covered with excrement and menstrual blood.” 49 For this reason, Höss preferred Zyklon-B:

There was no noticeable change in the bodies and no sign of convulsions or discolorations. Only after the bodies had been left lying for some time, that is to say after several hours, did the usual death stains appear in the places where they had lain. Soiling through opening of the bowels was also rare. There were no signs of wounding of any kind. The faces showed no distortion. 50

 For example, on one rare occasion when Höss chose to observe the gassings through a peephole in the gas chamber door, he noticed:

"those who were standing nearest to the induction vents were killed at once. It can be said that about one-third died straightaway. The remainder staggered about and began to scream and struggle for air. The screaming, however, soon changed to the death rattle and in a few minutes all lay still." 53
```
  
It says too that as they built more chambers, they improved the design so the gas would disperse quicker, as to kill more instantly.

 ```
A few months later, in June of 1942, Brack felt it important to remind Himmler of the potential advantages of sterilization over killing. “Castration by X-rays…is not only relatively cheap but can also be performed on many thousands in the shortest time.” 83

Having come to this conclusion, Brack ignored it completely and continued with the following fantastic scheme: The persons to be “processed”…would step up to a counter to be asked some questions or to fill out forms. Thus occupied, the unsuspecting candidate for sterilization would face the window for two or three minutes while the official sitting behind the counter would throw a switch which would release X-rays through two tubes pointing at the victim. With twenty such counters (cost: 20,000-30,000 marks apiece) 3000-4000 persons could be sterilized daily. 78

Decent Germans, according to Himmler, were never unnecessarily cruel. As he said in the same speech: “We shall never be rough and heartless when it is not necessary, that is clear. We Germans, who are the only people in the world who have a decent attitude towards animals, will also assume a decent attitude towards these human animals.”

In 1944, as Clemens Giese and Waldemar Kahler (both involved in the introduction of the November 1933 Nazi animal protection laws) noted:

"The animals protection movement, strongly promoted by the National Socialist government, has long demanded that animals be given anesthesia before being killed. The overwhelming majority of the German people have long condemned killing without anesthesia, a practice universal among Jews though not confined to them, …as against the cultivated sensitivities of our society." 68

Perpetrator perceptions over “humane” methods of killing might help increase our understanding of what it was that was so moderate about German anti-semitism. That is, unlike the Eastern Europeans and their barbaric pogroms where Jews were clubbed to death by the “Death-dealer of Kovno,” most “moderately antisemitic” Germans would only kill Jews with more “humane”—clean, emotionally distant, and civilized—methods.

in Rumania even the S.S. were taken aback, and occasionally frightened, by the horrors of old-fashioned, spontaneous pogroms on a gigantic scale; they often intervened to save Jews from sheer butchery, so that the killing could be done in what, according to them, was a civilized way.

  
The problem, however, with this moderate anti-semitism was that it stimulated a demand for a more “humane” and “civilized” method of killing that happened als

```
# Fences (Theater Play)
**FENCES (Theater Play)**
#reflection #reflection-on-media #theater-play
```
No, you don't understand Maslow's hierarchy of need. The father is consumed with maintaining the first two levels, while the son is thinking about the third. As I stated before, it was very difficult for black fathers to maintain the first two levels due to racism, etc..Because Troy was able to maintain the first two levels to some degree, the son had the luxury to start yapping about the third level ("his emotional needs") If you analyze the play, you can see that with each generation, as the black middle class grows, different needs are being introduced or developed. Troy was at level two (concerned about food/shelter and safety). Troy's father was at level one (concerned only about food/shelter--he cared nothing for Troy's safety, which was why Troy ran away from home). Listen to the story he tells of his own father in the play. It's scary. One can assume that Cory, being the next generation, will provide three levels of need to his son, but will fail with the fourth (he will provide food/shelter, safety, love/belonging, but won't provide esteem) and his son will probably come to him one day and asked him some "damn fool question," about esteem the way Cory asked his father about "being liked" and the cycle of father-son relationships starts over again.
```

# Evangelion
Evangelion thoughts
#reflection-on-media #reflection #scifi #consciousness #anime

so i read what you said

  

but how do we carry his weight

  

the character in nge keep talk about escaping from reality

  

escaping reality is the only way to not

  

they also keep talking about hate

  

hate is a concept for children

  

i believe that hate comes from an inner hatred

  

and a rejection of responsibility

  

for the hate itself

  

damn man spreading the good word back in 1995

  

take care yo self

  

cause no one else has to

  

also great message that you are not a self

  

a collection of relative selves

  

they also try to break down the concept of absolutes

  

absolute thinking is depressive thinking so my therapist said

  

"has it took you this long to realize that? you idiot!"

  

Right now Im taking the ending as "you, or whatever elements constitute the concept of you, are forever alone. we construct our reality on how we perceived to be perceived, because they are our only reference points. all truths are relative. cheesy, but groundwork.

  

To hate, be it the world, be it others, to hate those that you fear will hurt you (possibly again), only reflects fear, fear of the lacking of a self. Thus creating a cycle of hate, the destruction and hatred of anything besides the perceived yet fleeting "self." **However, in a world where no one exists, you cease to exist, as there is no delineation between the self and the other.** (Ergo the famous "you get what you wish for.")

  

Cheesy as it sounds, one must face who they are, in its entirety, and why they do what they do. You are the only one that can, and live. 

  

The show examines this issue through the presentation of a hive mind, where without the privacy, we can not develop multiple personalities for different settings, one is trapped by their "true" absolute identity, as any and all judgement is absolute and external.  
  
("You sleep with guys to get the love your father never gave you, but they abandon you").  
  
Should we give up our responsibility of defining reality to the hive mind, in our weakness, we give up the agency to choose for ourselves.  
  
I think to summarize, there is forever the internal debate of truth. What I perceive to be true will be more powerful to me than what is. This is simultaneously a human advantage and disadvantage. The show, nor I, have answers to the life question of what is truth. However, I believe if our conscious expected results do not occur, we must address the deeper truth of what we desire, our subconscious wishes. Approach the absolute truth, knowing well we will never make it there, until when our subconscious and conscious desires are aligned, and the results what we wish them to be.

**THOUGHT - EVANGELION**

Keeping others at a distance prevents betrayal however, if you avoid this pain, you must endure the pain of loneliness 

Men can not erase this sadness, because men are fundamentally alone

  

Man must endure pain in his heart. And because the heart is so sensitive to pain, some believe life is pain 

  

But if I am to return to everything there is at that point no longer a difference between the concept of me and nothing

  

THOUGHT QUESTION - DEMONS : We describer our disorders as “demons” and by separating them from ourselves we can draw distance which is comfortable but is it really better?

THOUGHTS - HIVEMIND : if we instantaneously knew how everyone felt, we would get nowhere because in order to change you must have opinions , so at your young age worry not about caring so much about others

# Remote Collaboration
**REMOTE COLLABORATION THOUGHTS**

The question is set up such that most people will probably answer that this course will be a lesson in remote work project management. Taking a project management class remotely also increases the difficulty level, which is probably a best practice. However I still believe the best work will be done in person, specifically in the realms of information bandwidth of physical interactions, is higher than digital currently, as well as in person accountability. Theres something primal about another human sitting across from you that demands higher levels of accountability then just the individual psyche over video chat can provide. Speaking again the higher difficulty of managing people remotely as Im sure the professor is experiencing right now, the text outlines "Winner Practices" which I feel should be weighed upon even more heavily for remote work. These were:

\-Clear Goals, by whom and by when

\-Grow internal project leaders

\-Streamline product delivery process 

\-Always measure product health metrics

  

As for benefits of virtual, it depends what is meant by benefit. The reading specifies some important areas, such as scope, time, cost and quality, that, dependent on project/organization values, would determine if virtual is a benefit. Virtual is a tradeoff for potentially decreases in cost, or as the textbook mentions potential global round the clock work, among other benefits relating to scope, time, cost, quality.

  

Generally however, I think from a project quality scope physically bests virtual given the information bandwidth I mentioned previously. Furthermore, in software, if time is also a function of quality given low quality code may result in high levels of debugging, and cost is a function of time, it would seem that for cost(time(quality)), a project, at least in the development aspect of software lifecycle, will be best undertaken in person.

# Japan Trip
**JAPAN AND KABUKI**
#reflection #travel #japan #kabuki
  
What I learned the first day in japan

Schoolgirls wear bowler hats and schoolboys wear fisherman's hats.

Never bring your luggage on the bus. Everyone stared in horror as 4 american sized luggages 

Nice construction workers let us through the construction and ran to us to help

Man stood and warned people that there was construction, was his only job

People stood at subway and said welcome, that was their only job

trucks have bad smog standards

  

Sationary store with 9 floors, each with counter

one floor had super silent lessons for making art, workers work on each floor making notebooks, paper, etc

  

Kabuki Show at Tokyo Kabuchiko theater in downtown Ginza.

Used subtitle machine, really helped to understand culture, history, and what was going on

Some dialogue was very modern 

Comedy was very modern feeling

Young women and maids portrayed by men, voices are somewhat demeaning and screechy

Chibacho was asked by the villain to marry her and she was allowed to refuse

  

singers in a wooden booth with traditional Japanese instruments

theater was not darkened

Since the play was adapted from a puppet show, there was a narrator accompanied with a koto player

man with loud drum

people in audience, maybe planted, shouting what we believed to be compliments

The play was about being disowned for not getting to a battleground first. Shame 

Very slow in narrator expository dialogue, but very fast comedic dialogue 

Japanese people next to me even fell asleep in the show, 

http://www.kabuki21.com/hs.php

**2018 California Code  
Vehicle Code - VEH  
DIVISION 12 - EQUIPMENT OF VEHICLES  
CHAPTER 2 - Lighting Equipment  
ARTICLE 3 - Rear Lighting Equipment  
Section 24600.**

**Universal Citation:** [CA Veh Code § 24600 (2018)](https://law.justia.com/citations.html)

24600.  

(f) Taillamps on vehicles manufactured on or after January 1, 1969, shall be mounted not lower than 15 inches nor higher than 72 inches, except that a tow truck, in addition to being equipped with the required taillamps, may also be equipped with two taillamps which may be mounted not lower than 15 inches nor higher than the maximum allowable vehicle height and as far forward as the rearmost portion of the driver’s seat in the rearmost position. The additional taillamps on a tow truck shall be lighted whenever the headlamps are lighted.

  

  

  

**2018 California Code

ARTICLE 3 - Rear Lighting Equipment  
Section 24602.**

24602.  

  

(2) The lamps shall be mounted not lower than 12 inches nor higher than 60 inches.

  

  

**2018 California Code  
Vehicle Code - VEH  
DIVISION 12 - EQUIPMENT OF VEHICLES  
CHAPTER 2 - Lighting Equipment  
ARTICLE 3 - Rear Lighting Equipment  
Section 24603.**

**Universal Citation:** [CA Veh Code § 24603 (2018)](https://law.justia.com/citations.html)

24603.  

  

(h) (1) Any vehicle may be equipped with supplemental stoplamps mounted to the rear of the rearmost portion of the driver’s seat in its rearmost position in addition to the lamps required to be mounted on the rear of the vehicle. Supplemental stoplamps installed after January 1, 1979, shall be red in color and mounted not lower than 15 inches above the roadway. The supplemental stoplamp on that side of a vehicle toward which a turn will be made may flash as part of the supplemental turn signal lamp.

  

(2) A supplemental stoplamp may be mounted inside the rear window of a vehicle, if it is mounted at the centerline of the vehicle and is constructed and mounted so as to prevent any light, other than a monitorial indicator emitted from the device, either direct or reflected, from being visible to the driver.

# Pipe Water Heater Maintenance
**PIPE / WATER HEATER MAINTENANCE**
#maintenance #piping #water #water-heater
Change water heater anode rod inside water heater because its a sacrificial bar that gets eaten

3-5 years
Get water heater with replaceable anode rod
Anode rod access should be easy 
Water heaters last 10 years without anode rod replacement 

Whole home water filter (remove trace elements that can damage piping such as calcium)

 Timers inside bathroom fan to allow steam to leave even after turning off light in room

Needs to be insulated 

Can not vent into ceiling 

 Seal grout once a year

Reciprocating saw grout cleaner, and floor mopper heavy duty 

Creating access panels behind shower assemblies and for sink-behind-cabinet assemblies

Drain water heater tank once a year 

Hot water circulator keeps particles moving and not stopping therefore do no corrode copper pipes

Hot water copper, cold pex 

The place where your plumbing is most likely to break is where the pipe is fastened to items like your sink, water heater, or even another pipe. [Orange County Re-piping](https://www.integrityrepiping.com/orange-repipe-copper-pex/) with flexible connections can give your plumbing some leeway in case of an earthquake. The pipes will have some room to move when everything starts shaking, instead of being forced to break off.

  

1.  Minimize velocity. Use larger diameter piping to keep velocities low:

cold line velocity should be less than 8 feet per second; hot lines should be less than 4 feet per second.

1.  Minimize hot water temperature.  Make sure return lines in a circulating hot water system have the same diameter as the supply lines.
2.  Avoid stagnant sections; minimize direction and size changes.
3.  Specify low-corrosivity water-flushable fluxes
4.  Avoid stagnant sections

updated: 2024-09-16T20:01
---
# Diversity - Harvard Review
DIVERSITY - Harvard Review Reflection from Project Management Class
#diversity
I can't say the jury is out on the phrase "research shows that diversity leads to better outcomes", as that is highly dependent on the project and quite vague, but I do see that diverse teams come up with a more diverse set of ideas, and that issues arise from implicit bias. To counteract implicit bias, I would probably have the team members go through some kind of collaborative bias training, not individual bias training.

Roleplay in particular is a extremely useful form of perspective taking. As the article mentioned, a diverse team was better off strictly if they had taken the perspective of their other team members. Extremely strange personal experience, relating to an improv game called Fiasco: My role in that scene was of a divorced mother at a PTA meeting where the ex husband had been tasked with bringing guacamole, and failed to do so. It was when the talking began I experienced a transcendent state where for a brief moment, I truly believed I was a divorced mother at a PTA meeting with my ex husband who forgot to bring the food (as representative of the irresponsibility which was the reason for our divorce), and felt one with the anxieties, sorrows, and painful events of that persona. Even thought it has only happened to me once, ever since then I have been a huge advocate for roleplay as a means of improving bias, seeing things from other's perspectives, and increasing empathy. If I had a choice, I would integrate roleplay highly into my team's implicit bias training.

If a team member was not working effectively in a diverse team, I would assume, as the article mentions, that the difference in values is greater than the difference in ideas, and at a certain point accept that we might need to change up the teams.

Lastly, it may be implied, but neither article mentioned it, and I think it worth mentioning, but "diversity" should also include all forms of cultural diversity, be it where you were born, what political affiliation you are, etc, where usually "diversity" is many times just shorthand for "ethnic diversity."


_Harvard Business Review_

_Why Diverse Teams Are Smarter by David Rock and Heidi Grant_

_Diverse Teams Feel Less Comfortable — and That’s Why They Perform Better by David Rock, Heidi Grant and Jacqui Grey_

# Genetic Health and Diet
**GENETIC HEALTH / DIET**
#health #diet #genetics
“race” to describe health disparity in societies characterized by racial categories

Geography as a basis for diet, and the future of genetic based health.

```
No claims are made for medicine, mainly an attempt at personal trial of the methodology. Race is not considered significant in this analysis, despite evidence that “Observer-reported race/ethnicity for European Americans and African Americans approximates genetic ancestry as well as self-reported race/ethnicity” given that due to “higher genetic diversity within races than between races, the use of race/ethnicity as a dissimilarity marker is misleading \[[107](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR107),[108](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR108)\].” 
```
  

Genetic-based medicine
```
Genetic medicine is a valuable tool in understanding hollistic human health. “Genomic researchers in medicine should focus on how genetic association results can be used to understand disease process in a way that can inform the clinical care of racial disparities rather than focusing merely on explaining health differences \[[78](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR78)\].” However, current genetic based medicine is considered “still in its infancy” and “Despite great progress in identifying genetic variants that influence human disease, most inherited risk remains unexplained.”
```
  
The solution to the mean time before clear cut genetic based medicine is preferential mating towards similar climate zones. Famously lactase intolerance

Differences in populations can be attributed to “a) a recent emergence of a variant that has not yet had time to spread to other populations,” ie geographic separation, and “b) natural selection in a specific local environment” or environmental selection pressures. Two populations, with similar selection pressures and environments, along with anthropological human preferential migration patterns along similar climate zones, ie less genetic and geographic separation, are valuable insights into possible congruous ancestral mutations, informing diet and self care. 

  
```
“Lactase persistence is an excellent example of the influence of natural selection on allelic frequency. Lactase persistence into adulthood is prevalent in Somali camel herders from Ethiopia where milk consumption continues beyond childhood \[[7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR7)\]. Positive selection in a geographic-specific manner has also been seen in genes that affect skin pigmentation \[[8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR8)\] and resistance to malaria \[[9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR9)\].” Knowing this, making informed choices on diet becomes easier to experiment with and narrow down.
```
  

Adjusting for Environment
```
Defining a locus and controls filters out emergent factors not based on environmental ancestry. “If a greater African ancestry is observed across the genome in asthmatic patients relative to controls, but no significant rise in local ancestry at a particular locus, this may point to a stronger role for socio-environmental factors (e.g., income, education, exposures to traffic, home, cigarettes) independent of ancestry \[[81](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR81),[86](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR86),[87](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4307746/%23CR87)\].”
```

Of course, this methodology is not foolproof, as there are certainly variants within ancestral populations when socio-environmental factors are controlled for. “For example, one person may have susceptibility variants that are common in one of their ancestral populations, but not the other (and the other way around for another individual from the same admixed pop

# Francis Fukuyama - Democracy's Failure to Perform
**Francis Fukuyama: Democracy's Failure to Perform**
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gF8CJSQf238
 
#Fukuyama #end-of-history #democracy #crony-capitalism #clientilism #Andrew-Jackson
 
fukuyama, who famously wrote about "the end of history", makes a interesting point that the current state of global emerging democracies, like India, Greece, Ukraine, Brazil, being full of crony capitalism, corruption, etc, are similar to American between the 1890s and the 1820s.

In the 1820s, Andrew Jackson runs on a populist platform and institutes crony capitalistic ideas to the government, IE appointment to government positions as political favors. This sets the precedent until the 1880s when a combination of factors, such as president James Garfield gets shot by a disgruntled would-be crony appointee, catalyzing a political movement in congress against this crony "clientilism".

 another interesting element, I had no idea that universal white male suffrage did not occur until Jacksonian democracy in the 1820s.

 ```
In the United States, the rise of Jacksonian democracy from the 1820s to 1850s led to a close approximation of universal manhood suffrage among white people being adopted in all states by 1856.\[3\] Poorer white male citizens gained representation; however, tax-paying requirements remained in five states until 1860, in two states until the 20th century, and many poor white people were later disenfranchised.\[3\] The expansion of suffrage was largely peaceful, excepting the Rhode Island Dorr Rebellion.
```

hes also making comparisons, actually much like dave chappel has recently, to the high levels of drug use and single parent households in the white working class community today, as a cause for the white nationalism/trumpian populist movement
```

```
# Fascism and Aesthetics
#aesthetics #utopia #morals 
Fascists believe that [liberal democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democracy "Liberal democracy") is obsolete and regard the complete mobilization of society under a [totalitarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Totalitarian "Totalitarian") [one-party state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-party_state "One-party state") as necessary to prepare a nation for armed conflict and to respond effectively to economic difficulties.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascism#cite_note-ReferenceB-9)

Sontag also enumerates some commonalities between fascist art and the official art of communist countries, such as the obeisance of the masses to the hero, and a preference for the monumental and the "grandiose and rigid" choreography of mass bodies. But whereas official communist art "aims to expound and reinforce a utopian morality", the art of fascist countries such as Nazi Germany "displays a utopian aesthetics – that of physical perfection", in a way that is "both prurient and idealizing".[\[265\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascism#cite_note-sontag-265)

"Fascist aesthetics", according to Sontag, "is based on the containment of vital forces; movements are confined, held tight, held in." And its appeal is not necessarily limited to those who share the fascist political ideology, because "fascism ... stands for an ideal or rather ideals that are persistent today under the other banners: the ideal of life as art, the cult of beauty, the fetishism of courage, the dissolution of alienation in ecstatic feelings of community; the repudiation of the intellect; the family of man (under the parenthood of leaders)."[\[265\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascism#cite_note-sontag-265)

# Trump, cptpp, Iran, usmca Trade Deal
**TRUMP, CPTPP, IRAN, USMCA**
#trump #cptpp #iran #usmca #capitalism #trade #political-economy
November 2020

"After Trump withdrew from the TPP, the remaining eleven signatories, known as the TPP-11, continued talks with the aim of salvaging a pact without the United States. Their effort was successful, leading to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, or CPTPP, which was signed in March 2018."

  

"The largest and most substantive change centers on intellectual property. In TPP negotiations, Washington pushed hard for longer copyright terms, automatic patent extensions, and separate protections for new technologies, including so-called biologics, a cutting-edge class of medications. Largely opposed by the other participants, these provisions were removed from the CPTPP."

  

"Tufts University, Global Development and Environment Institute study by Jeronim Capaldo and Alex Izurieta: estimated that all TPP participants would lose 770,000 jobs and non-TPP developing economies would lose 4.5 million jobs."

  

"First, the US had asked for additional time to be added to patents if parties experienced delays. These provisions have been suspended. Second, several highly controversial issues related to pharmaceutical patents were removed, including the whole section on biologics (18.51) and patent test data (18.50). Third, the TPP11 no longer has several sections related to new ways of protecting technology and information, including technological protection measures (TPMs), rights management information, encrypted satellite and cable signals, and safe harbors for internet service providers (ISPs). Finally, the copyright term length has not been extended to life of the creator plus 70 years, but is reset to life plus 50 years."

\--------------------------------------

from what I can tell despite Iran having a few flub ups that could be used as reason for leaving the deal, Trumps stance benefits american oil and weapons industries more, which can be a good or bad thing depending on your outlook

  

I am personally of the stance that cheap chinese manufacturing powered by coal, if aimed at producing renewables and electric infrastructure, such as trains, is overall better for the war on climate change

  

expensive solar panel american manufacturing aint gonna cut it

  

in the mean time the Chinese have been working on RCEP, positioned to decrease asian nations dependence on US

  

\-------------------

tldr: Trump's CPTPP is basically the same as the TPP but it reduces intellectual property regulation, which hurts entrenched US interests in biomedical/pharma, film and media, tech, but of course allows for the free-er flow of ideas which arguably from an market based perspective benefits everyone, hypothetically

  

tldr2: Iran deal, despite some flubs on Iranian side, was bad for US, Saudi, and Israeli guns and oil. What is was good for is more nebulous

  

tldr3: IMO, Cheap chinese manufacturing of renewables and electronics, even if based on coal, is better for the global war on climate change

# The Real World
**THE REAL WORLD** 
No Date
#military #college #university

Bachelor's degree college and non commissioned enlisted service military are not representative of real life, in the sense that they stray further from the baseline average of human social experience, like an anomalous outlying blip on the timeline of human lifespan and the broader average human experience. Firstly, defining the term “real life,” much of assumed life is adulthood, as humans live on average more than 60 years of age, and thus the largest chunk of that life, the working career, is the closest we can get to the term “real life,” given that the term refers to human experience in broader society. What we can say is that greater than age 18-26 represents “adulthood,” which continues on until death in the US, on average 60 years of age. The difference being greater than 34, greater than the 18-26 years of adolescence, suggests that the majority of working career, that is working a job for monetary income / fulfillment of living expenses, composes the largest part of human existence. 

Secondly, in terms of average temporal human experience, the closer an experience to this center of the bell curve, the more likely they will have a grasp or perception of the baseline of human experience. This does not disparage experiences farther from the mean as “better” or “worse,” simply farther from the norm of what the population in question experiences. 

The example of workers on an oil rig was posited. While living on the oil rig, their population is separated from as much outward stimuli of popular culture as someone in an urban area would be exposed to. They may develop specifics their own culture and nuances only found in their population, as all populations do. What separates oil workers from office workers is that the majority of the population of the united states does not work on oil rigs. Similar to the narrative of the prisoner who must be reintegrated into society after their time, it is a corollary that the lesser degree of communication of stimulus from broader popular culture and human interaction, the farther one is the mean of human experience. 

Why college and the military then, are farther from “real life,” is that they stray from this average human experience in both the temporary and socially. 

The military, if only a non administrative role, is about 8 years (according to J), assumedly starting at 18, at which point the career of officer then begins or the soldier is reintegrated into “real life.” Similarly, when a college student leaves school and begins their career job, no longer supported by their parents financially, they too must enter the “real world.”

**CARRIBEAN AND MATRIARCHY - REFLECTION**

One can expect a feminist backlash to this information since its basic conclusion

is that women's liberation to date in the Caribbean has not been the direct outcome of

women's assertive actions, but more the unintentional and indirect result of male conflict. But support for this conclusion is to be found in the observation that the Caribbean

region presents the interesting paradox of the ~oexistence of the greatest degree of women's

liberation anywhere in t' ~ world - including North America and Europe- with the absence of any organized militant feminist movement championing the cause of women.

  

The hypothesis postulated, together with evidence presented, asserts that conflicts

between males of the different segments of Caribbean society has produced the matrifocal forms observed and the liberation of Caribbean women as an unintended consequence. The intention of the dominant group is to keep the male of the subordinate

group marginal, and hence most of the opportunities of upward mobility made available

to the subordinate group are biased in favour of females.

  

the paper also mentions that this was a strategy that originated with the british

  

Errol Miller (1988) The Rise of Matriarchy in the Caribbean, Caribbean Quarterly, 34:3-4, 1-21, DOI: 10.1080/00086495.1988.11829430 

  

It is a form of gendered behaviour, which tells us that men should be powerful, wealthy and have status.

  

Matriarchs were frequent in the UK before women were granted much access to or equality in the public sphere. When women had little influence in the 'public' domain' it is no wonder they would assert more influence domestically. 

[https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/fran-hall/is-the-matriarchal-woman-\_b\_1462366.html?guccounter=1&guce\_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce\_referrer\_sig=AQAAAD6MwYoXgL8c8rPTN\_RlWyo2evSIiBfSV2iZ0WEirNfrQy2ZUege6tq4UJ40ayo0fYYMjGzLsZ8vBqdOJ9VWBewQxfYj9YxbUNEF8DrdVR-gEmKOpiUXtA7Ur8PdM-VddfpvAsXIix\_v0QvbI-vaG5i16Q5t3JsNqoZdiXdtUi-o](https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/fran-hall/is-the-matriarchal-woman-_b_1462366.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAD6MwYoXgL8c8rPTN_RlWyo2evSIiBfSV2iZ0WEirNfrQy2ZUege6tq4UJ40ayo0fYYMjGzLsZ8vBqdOJ9VWBewQxfYj9YxbUNEF8DrdVR-gEmKOpiUXtA7Ur8PdM-VddfpvAsXIix_v0QvbI-vaG5i16Q5t3JsNqoZdiXdtUi-o)

  

 In addition, before contraception was widely available families were larger and more often poorer, necessitating a permanent figure to run the house. Thus many talented women would have found themselves excluded from the workforce and bound to the home. But it is a particular approach to running the home that makes someone a matriarch.

This means often mothers are raising children alone, or with the support of the grandmother as there are also high rates of teenage pregnancy. Related to this, are the worryingly high crime rates amongst young men. There is a heavy Christian influence, praising the strong family unit. All of this is coupled of course with high poverty rates.
```
